editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The knight of the burning pestle.

quote.l: Ad libros et ad haec musarum dona vocares:
Boeotum in crasso iurares aëre natos.
quote.bibl: Horat. in Epist. ad Oct. Aug.

div.p: London, printed for Walter burr, and are to be sold at the sign of the crane in Paul's churchyard. 1613.

div.head: To his many ways endeared friend master Robert Keysar.
div.p:
Sir, this unfortunate child, who in eight days (As lately I have learned) was begotten and born soon after, was by his parents (Perhaps because he was so unlike his brothers) exposed to the wide world, who for want of judgement, or not understanding the privy mark of irony about it (Which showed it was no offspring of any vulgar brain) utterly rejected it: so that for want of acceptance it was even ready to give up the ghost, and was in danger to have been smothered in perpetual oblivion, if you (Out of your direct antipathy to ingratitude) had not been moved both to relieve and cherish it: wherein I must needs commend both your judgement, understanding, and singular love to good wits; you afterwards sent it to me, yet being an infant and somewhat ragged, I have fostered it privately in my bosom these two years,
and now to show, my love return it to you, clad in good lasting clothes, which scarce memory will wear out, and able to speak for itself; and withal, as it telleth me, desirous to try his fortune in the world, where if yet it be welcome, both father and foster-father, nurse and child, have their desired end. If it be slighted or traduced, it hopes his father will beget him a younger brother, who shall revenge his quarrel, and challenge the world either of fond and merely literal interpretation, or illiterate misprision. Perhaps it will be thought to be of the race of don Quixote: we both may confidently swear, it is his elder above a year; and therefore may (By virtue of his birthright) challenge the wall of him. I doubt not but they will meet in their adventures, and I hope the breaking of one staff will make them friends; and perhaps they will combine themselves, and travel through the world to seek their adventures. So I commit him to his good fortune, and myself to your love.

div.head: The famous history of the knight of the burning pestle.
div.l: From all that's near the court, from all that's great
Within the compass of the city-walls,
We now have brought our scene.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Hold your peace goodman boy.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: What do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: That you have no good meaning: this seven years there hath been plays at this house, I have observed it, you have still girds at citizens; and now you call your play, the London merchant. Down with your title boy, down with your title.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Are you a member of the noble city?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: And a freeman?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Yea, and a grocer.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: So grocer, then by your sweet favour, we intend no abuse to the city.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p:
No sir, yes sir, if you were not resolved to play the Jacks, what need you study for new subjects, purposely to abuse your betters? why could not you be contented, as well as others, with the legend of Whittington, or the life and death of sir Thomas Gresham? with the building of the royal exchange?
or the story of Queen Elinor, with the rearing of London bridge upon woolsacks?

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: You seem to be an understanding man: what would you have us do sir?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Why present something notably in honour of the commons of the city.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Why what do you say to the life and death of fat drake, or the repairing of fleet-privies?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I do not like that, but I will have a citizen, and he shall be of my own trade.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: O you should have told us your mind a month since, our play is ready to begin now.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: 'Tis all one for that, I will have a grocer, and he shall do admirable things.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: What will you have him do?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Marry I will have him —

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Husband, husband.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Peace mistress.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Hold thy peace Rafe, I know what I do I warrant tee. Husband, husband.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: What sayst thou coney?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Let him kill a lion with a pestle husband, let him kill a lion with a pestle.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: So he shall, I'll have him kill a lion with a pestle.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Husband, shall I come up husband?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I coney. Rafe help your mistress this way: pray gentlemen make her a little room, I pray you sir lend me your hand to help up my wife: I thank you sir. So.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: By your leave gentlemen all, I'm something troublesome, I'm a stranger here, I was ne'er at one of these plays as they say, before; but I should have seen Jane shore once, and my husband hath promised me any time this twelvemonth to carry me to the bold Beauchams, but in truth he did not, I pray you bear with me.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Boy, let my wife and I have a couple stools, and then begin, and let the grocer do rare things.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p:
But sir, we have never a boy to play him, every
one hath a part already.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Husband, husband, for god's sake let Rafe play him, beshrew me if I do not think he will go beyond them all.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Well remembered wife, come up Rafe: I'll tell you gentlemen, let them but lend him a suit of reparel, and necessaries, and by gad, if any of them all blow wind in the tail on him, I'll be hanged.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I pray you youth let him have a suit of reparel, I'll be sworn gentlemen, my husband tells you true, he will act you sometimes at our house, that all the neighbours cry out on him: he will fetch you up a couraging part so in the garret, that we are all as feared I warrant you, that we quake again: we'll fear our children with him if they be never so unruly, do but cry, Rafe comes, Rafe comes to them, and they'll be as quiet as lambs. Hold up thy head Rafe, show the gentlemen what thou canst do, speak a huffing part, I warrant you the gentlemen will accept of it.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Do Rafe, do.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: By heaven methinks it were an easy leap
To pluck bright honour from the pale-faced moon,
Or dive into the bottom of the sea,
Where never fathom line touched any ground,
And pluck up drowned honour from the lake of hell.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: How say you gentlemen, is it not as I told you?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay gentlemen, he hath played before, my husband says, Musidorus before the wardens of our company.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Ay, and he should have played Jeronimo with a shoemaker for a wager.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: He shall have a suit of apparel if he will go in.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: In Rafe, in Rafe, and set out the grocery in their kind, if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I warrant our Rafe will look finely when he's dressed.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: But what will you have it called?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: The grocer's honour.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: methinks the knight of the burning pestle were better.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I'll be sworn husband, that's as good a name as can be.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Let it be so, begin, begin, my wife and I will sit down.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: I pray you do.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: What stately music have you? you have shawms.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Shawms? no.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: No? I'm a thief if my mind did not give me so. Rafe plays a stately part, and he must needs have shawms: I'll be at the charge of them myself, rather then we'll be without them.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: So you are like to be.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Why and so I will be: there's two shillings, let's have the waits of Southwark, they are as rare fellows as any are in England; and that will fetch them all o'er the water with a vengeance, as if they were mad.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: You shall have them: will you sit down then?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Ay, come wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sit you merry all gentlemen, I'm bold to sit amongst you for my ease.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.l: From all that's near the court, from all that's great.
Within the compass of the city-walls,
We now have brought our scene: fly far from hence
All private taxes, immodest phrases,
Whate'er may but show like vicious:
For wicked mirth never true pleasure brings,
But honest minds are pleased with honest things.
Thus much for that we do: but for Rafe's part
You must answer for yourself.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Take you no care for Rafe, he'll discharge himself I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: i'faith gentlemen I'll give my word for Rafe.

div.head: Actus primi,
Scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter merchant, and Jasper his prentice.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Sirrah, I'll make you know you are my prentice,
And whom my charitable love redeemed
Even from the fall of fortune, gave thee heat
and growth, to be what now thou art, new cast thee,
Adding the trust of all I have at home,
In foreign staples, or upon the sea
To thy direction, tied the good opinions
Both of myself and friends to thy endeavours,
So fair were thy beginnings, but with these,
As I remember, you had never charge,
To love your master's daughter, and even then,
When I had found a wealthy husband for her,
I take it, sir, you had not; but however ,
I'll break the neck of that commission,
And make you know you are but a merchant's factor.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Sir, I do liberally confess I am yours,
Bound, both by love and duty, to your service;
In which, my labour hath been all my profit;
I have not lost in bargain, nor delighted
To wear your honest gains upon my back,
Nor have I given a pension to my blood,
Or lavishly in play consumed your stock.
These, and the miseries that do attend them,
I dare, with innocence, proclaim are strangers
To all my temperate actions; for your daughter,
If there be any love, to my deservings,
Born by her virtuous self, I cannot stop it?
Nor, am I able to refrain her wishes.
She's private to herself and best of knowledge,
Whom she'll make so happy as to sigh for.
Besides, I cannot think you mean to match her,
Unto a fellow of so lame a presence,
One that hath little left of nature in him.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: 'Tis very well sir, I can tell your wisdom
How all this shall be cured.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Your care becomes you.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: And thus it must be sir, I here discharge you
My house and service, take your liberty,
And when I want a son I'll send for you.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: These be the fair rewards of them that love.
O you that live in freedom never prove
the travel of a mind led by desire.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Why, how now friend, struck with my father's thunder?

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Struck and struck dead unless the remedy
Be full of speed and virtue; I am now,
What I expected long, no more your fathers.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: But mine.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: But yours, and only yours I am,
That's all I have to keep me from the statute,
You dare be constant still.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: O fear me not,
In this I dare be better than a woman.
Nor shall his anger, nor his offers move me,
Were they both equal to a prince's power.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: You know my rival?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes and love him dear
Even as I love an ague, or foul weather,
I prithee Jasper fear him not.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: O no,
I do not mean to do him so much kindness,
But to our own desires, you know the plot
We both agreed on.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes, and will perform
My part exactly.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: I desire no more,
Farewell, and keep my heart, 'tis yours.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I take it,
He must do miracles makes me forsake it.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Fie upon am little infidels, what a matter's here now? well, I'll be hanged for a halfpenny, if there be not some abomination knavery in this play, well, let 'em look to't, Rafe must come, and if there be any tricks a brewing, —

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Let 'em brew and bake too husband, a god's name, Rafe will find all out I warrant you, and they were older than they are, I pray my pretty youth is Rafe ready.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He will be presently.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Now I pray you make my commendations unto him, and withal carry him this stick of liquorice, tell him his mistress sent it him, and bid him bite a piece, 'twill open his pipes the better, say.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Come sir, she's yours, upon my faith she's yours
You have my hand, for other idle lets
Between your hopes and her, thus, with a wind
They are scattered and no more: my wanton prentice,
that like a bladder, blew himself with love,
I have let out, and sent him to discover
New masters yet unknown.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: I thank you sir,
Indeed I thank you sir, and ere I stir
It shall be known, however you do deem,
I am of gentle blood and gentle seem.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: O sir, I know it certain.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Sir my friend,
Although, as writers say, all things have end,
And that we call a pudding, hath his two
Oh let it not seem strange I pray to you,
If in this bloody simile, I put
My love, more endless, then frail things or gut.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Husband, I prithee sweet lamb tell me one thing, but tell me truly: stay youths I beseech you, till I question my husband.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: What is it mouse?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sirrah, didst thou ever see a prettier child? how it behaves itself, I warrant ye, and speaks, and looks, and pearts up the head? I pray you brother, with your favour, were you never none of m. Monkester's scholars?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Chicken, I prithee heartily contain thyself, the children are pretty children, but when Rafe comes, lamb.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I when Rafe comes coney; well my youth, you may proceed

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Well sir, you know my love, and rest, I hope,
Assured of my consent, get but my daughters,
And wed her when you please; you must be bold,
And clap in close unto her, come, I know
You have language good enough to win a wench.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A whoreson tyrant has been an old stringer in's days I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: I take your gentle offer and withal
Yield love again for love reciprocal.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: What luce within there.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Called you sir?

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: I did.
Give entertainment to this gentleman
And see you be not froward: to her sir,
My presence will but be an eyesore to you.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Fair mistress Luce, how do you, are you well?
Give me your hand and then I pray you tell,
How doth your little sister, and your brother?
And whether you love me or any other.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Sir, these are quickly answered.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: So they are.
Where women are not cruel: but how far
Is it now distant from this place we are in,
Unto that blessed place your father's warren.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: What makes you think of that sir?

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Even that face
For stealing rabbits whilom in that place,
God Cupid, or the keeper, I know not whether
Unto my cost and charges brought you thither,
And there began.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Your game sir.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Let no game,
Or any thing that tendeth to the same.
Be evermore remembered, thou fair killer
For whom I sat me down and broke my tiller.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: There's a kind gentleman, I warrant you, when will you do as much for me George?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Beshrew me sir, I am sorry for your losses,
But as the proverb says, I cannot cry,
I would you had not seen me.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: So would I.
Unless you had more maw to do me good.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Why, cannot this strange passion be withstood,
Send for a constable and raise the town.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: O no, my valiant love will batter down
Millions of constables, and put to flight,
Even that great watch of midsummer day at night.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Beshrew me sir, 'twere good I yielded then,
Weak women cannot hope, where valiant men
Have no resistance.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Yield then, I am full
Of pity, though I say it, and can pull
Out of my pocket, thus, a pair of gloves,
Look Lucy, look, the dog's tooth, nor the doves
Are not so white as these; and sweet they be,
And whipped about with silk, as you may see.
If you desire the price, suit from your eye,
A beam to this place, and you shall espy
F. s. which is to say, my sweetest honey,
They cost me three and two pence, or no money.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Well sir, I take them kindly, and I thank you,
What would you more?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Why then farewell.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Nor so, nor so, for lady I must tell,
Before we part, for what we met together,
God grant me time, and patience, and fair weather.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Speak and declare your mind in terms so brief.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: I shall, than first and foremost for relief
I call to you, I if that you can afford it,
I care not at what price, for on my word, it
Shall be repaid again, although it cost me
More than I'll speak of now, for love hath tossed me,
In furious blanket like a tennis ball,
And now I rise aloft, and now I fall.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Alas good gentleman, alas the day.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: I thank you heartily, and as I say,
Thus do I still continue without rest,
I'th' morning like a man, at night a beast,
Roaring and bellowing mine own disquiet,
That much I fear, forsaking of my diet,
Will bring me presently to that quandary,
I shall bid all adieu:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Now by s. marry
That were great pity.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: So it were beshrew me,
Then ease me lusty luce, and pity show me.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Why sir, you know my will is nothing worth
Without my father's grant, get his consent,
And than you may with assurance try me.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: The worshipful your sire will not deny me.
For I have asked him, and he hath replied,
Sweet master Humphrey, Luce shall be thy bride.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Sweet master Humphrey then I am content.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: And so am I intruth.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yet take me with you,
There is another clause must be annexed,
And this it is, I swore and will perform it;
No man shall ever joy me as his wife
But he that stole me hence, if you dare venture
I am yours; you need not fear, my father loves you,
If not farewell for ever.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Stay nymph, stay,
I have a double gelding coloured bay,
Sprung by his father from barbarian kind,
Another for myself, though somewhat blind,
Yet true as trusty tree.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I am satisfied,
And so I give my hand, our course must lie
Through Waltham forest, where I have a friend
Will entertain us, so farewell sir Humphrey,
And think upon your business.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Though I die,
I am resolved to venture life and limb,
For one so young, so fair, so kind, so trim.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: By my faith and troth George, and as I am virtuous, it is e'en the kindest young man that ever trod on shoe leather, well, go thy ways if thou hast her not, 'tis not thy fault 'faith.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I prithee mouse be patient, 'a shall have her, or I'll make some 'em smoke for't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: That's my good lamb George, fie, this stinking tobacco kills men, would there were none in England, now I pray gentlemen, what good does this stinking tobacco? do you nothing, I warrant you make chimneys a your faces: oh husband, husband, now, now, there's Rafe, there's Rafe.

div.stage: Enter Rafe like a Grocerin's shop, with two prentices reading Palmerin of England.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Peace fool, let Rafe alone, hark you Rafe; do not strain yourself too much at the first, peace, begin Rafe.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p:
Then Palmerin and Trineus snatching their lances from their dwarfs, and clasping their helmets galloped amain after the giant, and Palmerin having gotten a sight of him, came posting amain, saying: stay traitorous thief, for thou mayst not so carry away her, that is worth the greatest lord in the world, and with these words gave him a blow on the shoulder, that he stroke him besides his elephant, and Trineus coming to the knight that had Agricola behind him, set him soon besides his horse, with his neck broken in the fall, so that the Princess getting out of the throng, between joy and grief said; all happy knight, the mirror of all such as follow arms, now may I be well assured of
the love thou bearest me, I wonder why the Kings do not raise an army of fourteen or fifteen hundred thousand men, as big as the army that the prince of Portigo brought against Rocicler, and destroy these giants, they do much hurt to wandering damsels, that go in quest of their knights.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Faith husband and Rafe says true, for they say the King of Portugal cannot sit at his meat, but the giants and the ettins will come and snatch it from him,

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Hold thy tongue, on Rafe.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: And certainly those knights are much to be commended, who neglecting their possessions, wander with a squire and a dwarf through the deserts to relieve poor ladies.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I by my faith are they Rafe, let 'em say what they will, they are indeed, our knights neglect their possessions well enough, but they do not the rest.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: There are no such courteous and fair well spoken knights in this age, they will call one the son of a whore, that Palmerin of England, would have called fair sir; and one that Rosicler would have called right beauteous damsel, they will call damned bitch.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'll be sworn will they Rafe, they have called me so an hundred times about a scurvy pipe of tobacco.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: But what brave spirit could be content to sit in his shop with a flappet of wood and a blue apron before him selling mithridate and dragon's water to visited houses, that might pursue feats of arms, and through his noble achievements procure such a famous history to be written of his heroic prowess.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Well said Rafe, some more of those words Rafe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: They go finely by my troth.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p:
Why should not I then pursue this course, both for the credit of myself and our company, for amongst all the worthy books of achievements I do not call to mind that I yet read of a grocer errant, I will be the said knight, have you heard of any, that hath wandered unfurnished of his squire and dwarf, my elder prentice
Tim shall be my trusty squire, and little George my dwarf, hence my blue apron, yet in remembrance of my former trade, upon my shield shall be portrayed, a burning pestle, and I will be called the knight o'th' burning pestle.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay, I dare swear thou wilt not forget thy old trade, thou wert ever meek.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Anon.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: My beloved squire, and George my dwarf, I charge you that from henceforth you never call me by any other name, but the right courteous and valiant knight of the burning pestle, and that you never call any female by the name of a woman or wench, but fair lady, if she have her desires, if not distressed damsel, that you call all forests and heaths deserts, and all horses' palfreys.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: This is very fine, faith, do the gentlemen like Rafe, think you, husband?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Ay, I warrant thee, the players would give all the shoes in their shop for him.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: My beloved squire Tim, stand out, admit this were a desert, and over it a knight errant pricking, and I should bid you inquire of his intents, what would you say?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sir, my master sent me, to know whether you are riding?

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: No, thus; fair sir, the right courteous and valiant knight of the burning pestle, commanded me to inquire, upon what adventure you are bound, whether to relieve some distressed damsels, or otherwise.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Whoreson blockhead cannot remember.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'faith, and Rafe told him on't before, all the gentlemen heard him, did he not gentlemen, did not Rafe tell him on't?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Right courteous and valiant knight of the burning pestle, here is a distressed damsel, to have a half pennyworth of pepper.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: That's a good boy, see, the little boy can hit it, by my troth it's a fine child.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p:
Relieve her with all courteous language, now shut up shop, no more my prentice, but my trusty
squire and dwarf, I must be my shield and arming-pestle.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Go thy ways Rafe, as I'm a true man, thou art the best on 'em all.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Rafe, Rafe.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: What say you mistress?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I prithee come again quickly sweet Rafe.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: By and by.

div.stage: Enter Jasper, and his mother mistress Merrithought.

sp.speaker: Mistress Merri.
sp.p: Give thee my blessing? No, I'll ne'er give thee my blessing, I'll see thee hanged first; it shall ne'er be said I gave thee my blessing, thou'rt thy fathers own son, of the right blood of the Merri-thoughts, I may curse the time that ere I knew thy father, he hath spent all his own, and mine too, and when I tell him of it, he laughs and dances, and sings, and cries, a merry heart lives long. And thou art a waste-thrift, and art run away from thy master, that loved thee well, and art come to me, and I have laid up a little for my younger son Michael, and thou think'st to bezzle that, but thou shalt never be able to do it. Come hither Michael, come Michael, down on thy knees, thou shalt have my blessing.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: I pray you mother pray to God to bless me.

sp.speaker: Mistress Merri.
sp.p: God bless thee: but Jasper shall never have my blessing, he shall be hanged first, shall he not Michael? how sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Yes forsooth mother and grace of God.

sp.speaker: Mistress Merri.
sp.p: That's a good boy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: i'faith it's a fine spoken child.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Mother, though you forget a parent's love,
I must preserve the duty of a child.
I ran not from my master, nor return
To have your stock maintain my idleness.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ungracious child I warrant him, hark how he chops logic with his mother: thou hadst best tell her she lies, do tell her she lies.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p:
If he were my son, I would hang him up by the
heels, and flay him, and salt him, whoreson haltersack.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: My coming only is to beg your love,
Which I must ever, though I never gain it,
And howsoever you esteem of me,
There is no drop of blood hid in these veins,
But I remember well belongs to you
That brought me forth, and would be glad for you
To rip them all again, and let it out.

sp.speaker: Mistress Merri.
sp.p: i'faith I had sorrow enough for thee (God knows) but I'll hamper thee well enough: get thee in thou vagabond, get thee in, and learn of thy brother Michael.

sp.speaker: Old Merri. within.
sp.p: Nose, nose, jolly red nose, and who gave thee this jolly red nose?

sp.speaker: Mistress Merri.
sp.l: Hark, my husband he's singing and hoiting,
And I'm fain to cark and care, and all little enough.
Husband, Charles, Charles Merithought.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.l: Nutmegs and ginger, cinnamon and cloves,
And they gave me this jolly red nose.

sp.speaker: Mistress Merri.
sp.p: If you would consider your state, you would have little lust to sing, iwis.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.p: It should never be considered while it were an estate, if I thought it would spoil my singing.

sp.speaker: Mistress Merri.
sp.p: But how wilt thou do Charles, thou art an old man, and thou canst not work, and thou hast not forty shillings left, and thou eatest good meat, and drinkest good drink, and laughest?

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.p: And will do.

sp.speaker: Mistress Merri.
sp.p: But how wilt thou come by it Charles?

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.p:
How? why how have I done hitherto this forty years? I never came into my dining room, but at eleven and six o'clock , I found excellent meat and drink a'th table, my clothes were never worn out, but next morning a tailor brought me a new suit; and without question it will be so ever: use makes perfectness. If all should fail, it is but a little
straining myself extraordinary, and laugh myself to death.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: It's a foolish old man this: is not he George?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Yes coney.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Give me a penny i'th purse while I live George.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I by lady coney, hold thee there.

sp.speaker: Mistress Merri.
sp.p: Well Charles, you promised to provide for Jasper, and I have laid up for Michael, I pray you pay Jasper his portion, he's come home, and he shall not consume Michael's stock: he says his master turned him away, but I promise you truly, I think he ran away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No indeed mistress Merrithought, though he be a notable gallows, yet I'll assure you his master did turn him away, even in this place 'twas i'faith within this half hour, about his daughter, my husband was by.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Hang him rogue, he served him well enough: love his master's daughter! by my troth coney if there were a thousand boys, thou wouldst spoil them all with taking their parts, let his mother alone with him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I George, but yet truth is truth.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.p: Where is Jasper, he's welcome however , call him in, he shall have his portion, is he merry?

sp.speaker: Mistress Merri.
sp.p: I foul chive him, he is too merry. Jasper, Michael.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.p: Welcome Jasper, though thou runnest away, welcome, God bless thee: 'tis thy mother's mind thou shouldst receive thy portion; thou hast been abroad, and I hope hast learned experience enough to govern it, thou art of sufficient years, hold thy hand: one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, there's ten shillings for thee, thrust thyself into the world with that, and take some settled course, if fortune cross thee, thou hast a retiring place, come home to me, I have twenty shillings left, be a good husband, that is, wear ordinary clothes, eat the best meat, and drink the best drink, be merry, and give to the poor, and believe me, thou hast no end of thy goods.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Long may you live free from all thought of ill,
And long have cause to be thus merry still.
But father?

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.p: No more words Jasper, get thee gone, thou hast my blessing, thy father's spirit upon thee. Farewell Jasper, but yet or ere you part (O cruel!) kiss me, kiss me sweeting, mine own dear jewel: so, now begone; no words.

sp.speaker: Mis. Mer.
sp.p: So Michael, now get thee gone too.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Yes forsooth mother, but I'll have my father's blessing first.

sp.speaker: Mis. Mer.
sp.p: No Michael, 'tis now matter for his blessing, thou hast my blessing, begone; I'll fetch my money and jewels, and follow thee: I'll stay no longer with him I warrant thee, truly Charles I'll begone too.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.p: What you will not.

sp.speaker: Mis. Merri.
sp.p: Yes indeed will I.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.p: Hey ho, farewell Nan, I'll never trust wench more again, if I can.

sp.speaker: Mis. Merri.
sp.p: You shall not think (When all your own is gone) to spend that I have been scraping up for Michael.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.p:
Farewell good wife, I expect it not; all I have to do in this world, is to be merry: which I shall, if the ground be not taken from me: and if it be,
When earth and seas from me are rest,
The skies aloft for me are left.

div.stage: Boy danceth. Music. Finis actus primi.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'll be sworn he's a merry old gentleman for all that. Hark, hark husband, hark, fiddles, fiddles; now surely they go finely. They say, 'tis present death for these fiddlers to tune their rebecks before the great Turks grace, is't not George? But look, look, here's a youth dances: now good youth do a turn ath' toe, sweet heart, i'faith I'll have Rafe come and do some of his gambols; he'll ride the wild mare gentlemen, 'twould do your hearts good to see him. I thank you kind youth, pray bid Rafe come.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Peace coney. Sirrah, you scurvy boy, bid the players send Rafe, or by gods — and they do not, I'll tear some of their periwigs beside their heads: this is all riff-raff .

div.head: Actus secundi
Scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: And how faith? how goes it now son Humphrey?

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Right worshipful, and my beloved friend
And father dear, this matters at an end.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: 'Tis well, it should be so, I'm glad the girl
Is found so tractable.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Nay she must whirl
From hence, and you must wink: for so I say,
The story tells, tomorrow before day.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: George, dost thou think in thy conscience now 'twil be a match? tell me but what thou thinkst sweet rogue, thou seest the poor gentleman (Dear heart) how it labours and throbs I warrant you, to be at rest: I'll go move the father fort.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: No, no, I prithee sit still honeysuckle, thoul't spoil all, if he deny him, I'll bring half a dozen good fellows myself, and in the shutting of an evening knocked up, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'll buss thee for that i'faith boy; well George, well, you have been a wag in your days I warrant you: but God forgive you, and I do with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: How was it son? you told me that tomorrow
Before day break, you must convey her hence.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: I must, I must, and thus it is agreed,
Your daughter rides upon a brown-bay steed,
I on a sorrel, which I bought of Brian,
The honest host of the red roaring lion
In Waltham situate: then if you may
Consent in seemly sort, lest by delay,
The fatal sisters come and do the office,
And then you'll sing another song.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Alas
Why should you be thus full of grief to me?
That do as willing as yourself agree
to any thing so it be good and fair,
Then steal her when you will, if such a pleasure
Content you both, I'll sleep and never see it,
To make your joys more full, but tell me why
You may not here perform your marriage?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: God's blessing a thy soul old man, i'faith thou art loath to part true hearts, I see, 'a has her Georg, and I'm as glad on't, well, go thy ways Humphrey, for a fair spoken man, I believe thou hast not thy fellow within the walls of London, and I should say the suburbs too, I should not lie, why dost not rejoice with me George?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: If I could but see Raph again, I were as merry as mine host i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: The cause you seem to ask, I thus declare,
Help me o muses nine, your daughter swear
A foolish oath, the more it was the pity,
Yet none but myself within this city,
Shall dare to say so, but a bold defiance
Shall meet him, were he of the noble science.
And yet she swear, and yet why did she swear?
Truly I cannot tell, unless it were
For her own ease, for sure sometimes an oath,
Being sworn thereafter is like cordial broth.
And this it was she swore, never to marry,
But such a one, whose mighty arm could carry
(As meaning me, for I am such a one)
Her bodily away through stick and stone,
Till both of us arrive, at her request,
Some ten miles off, in the wild Waltham forest.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: If this be all, you shall not need to fear
Any denial in your love, proceed,
I'll neither follow, nor repent the deed.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Goodnight, twenty good-nights, and twenty more.
And 20 more good-nights, that makes threescore.

div.stage: Enter mistress Mery-thought, and her son Michael.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Come Michael, art thou not weary boy?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: No forsooth mother not I.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Where be we now child?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Indeed forsooth mother I cannot tell, unless we be at Mile-end, is not all the world Mile-end, mother?

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: No Michael, not all the world boy, but I can assure thee Michael, Mile-end is a goodly matter, there has been a pitch-field my child between the naughty spaniels and the Englishmen, and the spaniels ran away Michael, and the Englishmen followed, my neighbour Coxstone was there boy, and killed them all with a birding piece.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Mother forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: What says my white boy?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Shall not my father go with us too?

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: No Michael, let thy father go snick-up, he shall never come between a pair of sheets with me again, while he lives, let him stay at home and sing for his supper boy, come child sit down, and I'll show my boy fine knacks indeed, look here Michael, here's a ring, and here's brooch, and here's a bracelet, and here's two rings more, and here's money and gold byth' eye my boy.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Shall I have all this mother?

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: I Michael thou shalt have all Michael.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: How likest thou this wench?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I would have Raph, George; I'll see no more else indeed-la, and I pray you let the youths understand so much by word of mouth, for I tell you truly, I'm afraid a my boy, come, come George, let's be merry and wise, the child's a fatherless child, and say they should put him into a straight pair of gaskins, 'twere worse than knotgrass, he would never grow after it.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Here's Raph, here's Raph.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: How do you Raph? you are welcome Raph, as I may say, it's a good boy, hold up thy head, and be not afraid, we are thy friends Raph, the gentlemen will praise thee Raph, if thou playst thy part with audacity, begin Raph a god's name.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: My trusty squire unlace my helm, give me my hat, where are we, or what desert may this be?

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.p: Mirror of knighthood, this is, as I take it, the perilous Waltham down, in whose bottom stands the enchanted valley.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p:
O Michael, we are betrayed, we are betrayed here
be giants, fly boy, fly boy, fly.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Lace on my helm again: what noise is this?
A gentle lady flying? the embrace
Of some uncourteous knight, I will relieve her.
Go squire, and say, the knight that wears this pestle,
In honour of all ladies, swears revenge
Upon that recreant coward that pursues her.
Go comfort her, and that same gentle squire
That bears her company.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.l: I go brave knight.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: My trusty dwarf and friend, reach me my shield,
And hold it while I swear: first by my knighthood,
Then by the soul of Amadis de Gaul,
My famous ancestor, then by my sword,
The beauteous Brionella girt about me,
By this bright burning pestle of mine honour,
The living trophy, and by all respect
Due to distressed damsels, here I vow
Never to end the quest of this fair lady,
And that forsaken squire, till by my valour
I gain their liberty.

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.l: Heaven bless the knight
That thus relieves poor errant gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I marry Rafe, this has some savour in't, I would see the proudest of them all offer to carry his books after him. But George, I will not have him go away so soon, I shall be sick if he go away, that I shall; call Rafe again George, call Rafe again, I prithee sweet heart let him come fight before me, and let's ha' some drums, and some trumpets, and let him kill all that comes near him, and thou lovest me George.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Peace a little bird, he shall kill them all and they were twenty more on 'em then there are.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Now fortune, if thou beest not only ill,
Show me thy better face, and bring about
Thy desperate wheel, that I may climb at length
And stand, this is our place of meeting,
If love have any constancy. O age!
Where only wealthy men are counted happy:
How shall I please thee? how deserve thy smiles?
When I am only rich in misery?
My father's blessing, and this little coin
Is my inheritance, a strong revenue,
From earth thou art, and to the earth I give thee,
There grow and multiply, whilst fresher air,
Breeds me a fresher fortune, how, illusion!
What hath the devil coined himself before me?
'Tis mettle good, it rings well, I am waking,
And taking too I hope, now god's dear blessing
Upon his heart that left it here, 'tis mine,
These pearls, I take it, were not left for swine.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I do not like that this unthrifty youth should embezzle away the money; the poor gentlewoman his mother will have a heavy heart for it God knows.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: And reason good, sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: But let him go, I'll tell Raph a tale in's ear shall fetch him again with a wanion I warrant him, if he be above ground, and besides George, here are a number of sufficient gentlemen can witness, and myself, and yourself, and the musicians, if we be called in question, but here comes Raph, George, thou shalt hear him speak, an he were an emperall.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Comes not sir squire again?

sp.speaker: Dwarf
sp.l: Right courteous knight,
Your squire doth come and with him comes the lady,
sp.stage: Enter mistress Merr: and Michael, and squire.
sp.l: For and the squire of damsels as I take it.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Madam if any service or devoir
Of a poor errant knight may right your wrongs,
Command it, I am pressed to give you succour,
For to that holy end I bear my armour,

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Alas sir, I am a poor gentlewoman, and I have lost my money in this forest.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Desert, you would say lady, and not lost
Whilst I have sword and lance, dry up your tears
Which ill befits the beauty of that face:
and tell the story, if I may request it,
Of your disastrous fortune.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Out alas, I left a thousand pound, a thousand pound, e'en all the money I had laid up for this youth, upon the sight of your mastership, you looked so grim, and as I may say it, saving your presence, more like a giant than a mortal man.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: I am as you are lady, so are they
All mortal, but why weeps this gentle squire.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Has he not cause to weep do you think, when he hath lost his inheritance?

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Young hope of valour, weep not, I am here
That will confound thy foe and pay it dear
Upon his coward head, that dares deny,
Distressed squires and lady's equity.
I have but one horse, on which shall ride
This lady fair behind me, and before
This courteous squire, fortune will give us more
Upon our next adventure; fairly speed
Beside us squire and dwarf to do us need.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Did not I tell you Nell what your man would do? by the faith of my body wench, for clean action and good delivery they may all cast their caps at him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And so they may i'faith, for I dare speak it boldly, the twelve companies of London cannot match him, timber for timber, well George, and he be not inveigled by some of these paltry players, I ha' much marvel, but George we ha' done our parts if the boy have any grace to be thankful.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Yes I warrant thee duckling.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Good mistress Luce however I in fault am
For your lame horse; you're welcome unto Waltham.
But which way now to go or what to say
I know not truly till it be broad day.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: O fear not master Humphrey, I am guide
For this place good enough.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Then up and ride,
Or if it please you walk for your repose,
or sit, or if you will go pluck a rose:
Either of which shall be indifferent,
To your good friend and Humphrey, whose consent
Is so entangled ever to your will,
As the poor harmless horse is to the mill.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Faith and you say the word we'll e'en sit down
And take a nap.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: 'Tis better in the town,
Where we may nap together, for believe me
To sleep without a snatch would mickle grieve me.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: You're merry master Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Humphrey
sp.l: So I am,
And have been ever merry from my dam.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Your nurse had the less labour.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Faith it may be,
Unless it were by chance I did bewray me.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Luce dear friend Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Here Jasper.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: You are mine.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: If it be so, my friend, you use me fine,
What do you think I am?

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: An arrant noddy

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: A word of obloquy, now by god's body,
I'll tell thy master for I know thee well.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Nay, and you be so forward for to tell,
Take that, and that, and tell him sir I gave it,
And say I paid you well.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: O sir I have it,
And do confess the payment, pray be quiet.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Go, get to your nightcap and the diet,
To cure your beaten bones.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Alas poor Humphrey
Get thee some wholesome broth with sage and comfry:
A little oil of roses and a feather,
To 'noint thy back withal.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: When I came hither,
Would I had gone to Paris with John Dorrie.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Farewell my pretty nump, I am very sorry
I cannot bear thee company.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Farewell,
The devil's dam was never so banged in hell.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
This young Jasper will prove me another things, a my conscience and he may be suffered; George, dost not see George how 'a swaggers, and flies at the very heads a fokes as
he were a dragon; well if I do not do his lesson for wronging the poor gentleman, I am no true woman, his friends that brought him up might have been better occupied, I wis, then ha' taught him these fegaries, he's e'en in the highway to the gallows, God bless him.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: You're too bitter, conny, the young man may do well enough for all this.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Come hither master Humphrey, has he hurt you? now beshrew his fingers for't, here sweet heart, here's some green ginger for thee, now beshrew my heart but a has peppernel in's head, as big as a pullet's egg, alas sweet lamb, how thy temples beat; take the peace on him sweet heart, take the peace on him.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: No, no, you talk like a foolish woman, I'll ha' Raph fight with him, and swing him up well-favouredly, sirrah boy come hither, let Raph come in and fight with Jasper.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ay, and beat him well, he's an unhappy boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir you must pardon us, the plot of our play lies contrary, and 'twill hazard the spoiling of our play.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Plot me no plots, I'll ha' Raph come out, I'll make your house too hot for you else.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why sir he shall, but if any thing fall out of order, the gentlemen must pardon us.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Go your ways goodman boy, I'll hold him a penny he shall have his bellyful of fighting now, ho here comes Raph, no more.

div.stage: Enter Raph, mistress merri: Michael, squire, and dwarf.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: What knight is that squire, ask him if he keep
The passage, bound by love of lady fair,
Or else but prickant.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Sir I am no knight,
But a poor gentleman, that this same night,
Had stolen from me on yonder green,
My lovely wife, and suffered to be seen
Yet extant on my shoulders such a greeting,
That whilst I live, I shall think of that meeting.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I Raph he beat him unmercifully, Raph, and thou sparest him Raph I would thou wert hanged.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: No more, wife no more.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Where is the caitiff wretch hath done this deed.
Lady your pardon, that I may proceed
Upon the quest of this injurious knight.
And thou fair squire repute me not the worse,
In leaving the great venture of the purse,
And the rich casket till some better leisure,

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Here comes the broker hath purloined my treasure.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Go, squire, and tell him I am here,
An errant knight at arms, to crave delivery
Of that fair lady to her own knights arms.
If he deny, bid him take choice of ground,
And so defy him.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.l: From the knight that bears
The golden pestle, I defy thee knight.
Unless thou make fair restitution.
Of that bright lady.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Tell the knight that sent thee
He is an ass, and I will keep the wench
And knock his head-piece.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Knight, thou art but dead,
If thou thou recall not thy uncourteous terms.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Break's pate Raph, break's pate Raph, soundly.

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.l: Come knight, I am ready for you, now your pestle
Shall try what temper, sir, your mortars off
With that he stood upright in his stirrups,
And gave the knight of the calf-skin such a knock,
That he forsook his horse and down he fell,
And then he leapt upon him and plucking of his helmet.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Nay, and my noble knight be down so soon,
Though I can scarely go I needs must run.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Run Raph, run Raph, run for thy life boy, Jasper comes, Jasper comes.

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: Come Luce, we must have other arms for you, Humphrey and golden pestle both adieu.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Sure the devil, God bless us, is in this springal,
why George, didst ever see such a fire-drake, I am afraid my boy's miscarried, if he be, though he were master Mery-thoughts son a thousand times, if there be any law in England I'll make some of them smart for't.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: No, no, I have found out the matter sweetheart, Jasper is enchanted, as sure as we are here, he is enchanted, he could no more have stood in Raph's hands, than I can stand in my lord majors, I'll have a ring to discover all enchantments, and Raph shall beat him yet: be no more vexed for it shall be so.

div.stage: Enter Raph, squire, dwarf, mistress Mery-thought and Michael.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O husband here's Raph again, stay Raph let me speak with thee, how dost thou Raph? art thou not shrewdly hurt? the soul great lung is laid unmercifully on thee, there's some sugar-candy for thee, proceed, thou shalt have another bout with him.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: If Raph had him at the fencing-school, if he did not make a puppy of him, and drive him up and down the school he should ne'er come in my shop more.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Truly master knight of the burning pestle I am weary.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Indeed la mother and I am very hungry.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Take comfort gentle dame, and you fair squire,
For in this desert there must needs be placed,
Many strong castles, held by courteous knights,
And till I bring you safe to one of those,
Is wear by this my order ne'er to leave you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Well said Raph, George, Raph was ever comfortable, was he not?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Yes duck.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I shall ne'er forget him, when we had lost our child, you know, it was strayed almost, alone, to puddle-wharf and the criers were abroad for it, and there it had drowned itself but for a sculler, Raph was the most comfortablest to me: peace mistress, says he, let it go, I'll get you another as good, did he not George? did he not say so?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Yes indeed did he mouse.

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.p: I would we had a mess of pottage, and a pot of drink, squire, and were going to bed.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p: Why we are at Waltham towns end, and that's the bell inn.

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.l: Take courage valiant knight, damsel, and squire
I have discovered, not a stone's cast off,
An ancient castle held by the old knight
Of the most holy order of the bell,
Who gives to all knights errant entertain:
There plenty is of food, and all prepared,
By the white hands of his own lady dear.
He hath three squires that welcome all his guests.
The first high chamberlino, who will see
Our beds prepared, and bring us snowy sheets,
Where never footman stretched his buttered hams.
The second hight Tastero, who will see
Our pots full filled and no froth therein.
The third a gentle squire Ostlero hight,
Who will our palfreys slick with wisps of straw,
And in the manger put them oats enough,
And never grease their teeth with candle snuff.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: That same dwarf's a pretty boy, but the squire's a grout-nole.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Knock at the gates my squire with stately lance.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.l: Who's there, you're welcome gentlemen, will you see a room?

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.l: Right courteous and valiant knight of the burning pestle,
This is the squire Tapstero.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Fair squire Tapstero, I a wand'ring knight,
Hight of the burning pestle, in the quest
Of this fair ladies casket, and wrought purse,
Losing myself in this vast wilderness
Am to this castle well by fortune brought,
Where hearing of the goodly entertain
Your knight of holy order of the bell
Gives to all damsels, and all errant knights,
I thought to knock, and now am bold to enter.

sp.speaker: Tapster.
sp.p: An't please you see a chamber, you are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: George I would have something done, and I cannot tell what it is.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: What is it Nell?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why George, shall Raph beat nobody again? prithee sweetheart let him.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: So he shall Nell, and if I join with him, we'll knock them all.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O George here's master Humphrey again now, that lost mistress Luce, and mistress Lucy's father, master Humphrey will do somebody's errant I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Father, it's true, in arms I ne'er shall clasp her,
For she is stolen away by your man Jasper.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I thought he would tell him.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Unhappy that I am to lose my child,
Now I begin to think on Jasper's words,
Who oft hath urged to me thy foolishness,
Why didst thou let her go? thou lov'st her not,
That wouldst bring home thy life, and not bring her.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Father forgive me, shall I tell you true,
Look on my shoulders they are black and blue.
Whilst to and fro fair luce and I were winding,
He came and basted me with a hedge binding.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Get men and horses straight, we will be there
Within this hour, you know the place again.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: I know the place, where he my loins did swaddle,
I'll get six horses, and to each a saddle.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Mean time I'll go talk with Jasper's father.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: George, what wilt thou lay with me now, that master Humphrey has not mistress Luce yet, speak George, what wilt thou lay with me?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: No Nell, I warrant thee Jasper is at Puckridge with her, by this.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Nay George, you must consider mistress Lucy's
feet are tender, and, besides, 'tis dark, and I promise you truly, I do not see how he should get out of Waltham forest with her yet.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Nay coney, what wilt thou lay with me that Raph has her not yet.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I will not lay against Raph honey, because I have not spoken with him, but look George, peace, here comes the merry old gentleman again.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: When it was grown to dark midnight,
And all were fast asleep,
In came Margaret's grimely ghost,
And stood at William's feet.
sp.p: I have money, and meat and drink before hand, till tomorrow at noon, why should I be sad? methinks I have half a dozen jovial spirits within me, I am three merry men, and three merry men, to what end should any man be sad in this world? give me a man that when he goes to hanging cries, troll the black bowl to me: and a woman that will sing a cath in her travel. I have seen a man come by my door, with a serious face, in a black cloak, without a hatband, carrying his head as if he looked for pins in the street, I have looked out of my window half a year after, and have spied that man's head upon London-bridge: 'tis vile, never trust a tailor that does not sing at his work, his mind is of nothing but filching.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Mark this George, 'tis worth noting: Godfrey my tailor, you know, never sings, and he had fourteen yards to make this gown, and I'll be sworn mistress Pennistone the draper's wife had one made with twelve.

sp.speaker: Old Mer:
sp.l: 'Tis mirth that fills the veins with blood,
More than wine, or sleep, or food.
Let each man keep his heart at ease,
No man dies of that disease.
He that would his body keep
From diseases, must not weep,
But whoever laughs and sings,
never he his body brings
Into fevers, gouts, or rheums,
Or lingeringly his longs consumes:
Or meets with aches in the bone,
Or catarrhs, or griping stone:
But contented lives for aye,
The more he laughs, the more he may.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Look George, how sayest thou by this George? is't not a fine old man? Now God's blessing a'thy sweet lips. When wilt thou be so merry George? Faith thou art the frowningst little thing when thou art angry, in a country.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Peace Coney, thou shalt see him taken down too I warrant thee; here's Luce's father come now.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: As you came from Walsingham, from that holy land, there met you not with my truelove by the way as you came

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: O master Merrithought! my daughter's gone.
This mirth becomes you not, my daughters gone.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.l: Why an if she be, what care I?
Or let her come or go, or tarry.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Mock not my misery, it is your son,
Whom I have made my own, when all forsook him,
Has stolen my only joy, my child away.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: He set her on a milk-white steed, and himself upon a grey,
He never turned his face again, but he bore her quite away.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Unworthy of the kindness I have shown
To thee, and thine: too late I well perceive
Thou art consenting to my daughter's loss.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: Your daughter, what a stir's here we year daughter? Let her go, think no more on her, but sing loud. If both my sons were on the gallows, I would sing, down, down, down: they fall down, and arise they never shall.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: O might I behold her once again,
And she once more embrace her aged sire.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.p: Fie, how scurvily this goes: and she once more embrace her aged sire? you'll make a dog on her, will ye? she cares much for her aged sire I warrant you.
sp.l: She cares cares not for her daddy, nor she cares not for her mammy,
For she is, she is, she is, she is my lord of Low-gaves' lassie.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: For this thy scorn, I will pursue
That son of thine to death.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.l: Do, and when you ha' killed him,
Give him flowers enough palmer: give him flowers enough,
Give him red, and white, and blew, green, and yellow.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: I'll fetch my daughter.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.p: I'll hear no more a your daughter, it spoils my mirth.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: I say I'll fetch my daughter.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.l: Was never man for ladies' sake, down, down,
Tormented as I poor sir Guy? de derry down,
For Lucy's sake, that lady bright, down, down,
As ever men beheld with eye? de derry down.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: I'll be revenged by heaven.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: How dost thou like this George?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Why this is well coney: but if Raph were hot once, thou shouldst see more.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: The fiddlers go again husband.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I Nell, but this is scurvy music: I gave the whoreson gallows money, and I think he has not got me the waits of Southwark, if I hear him not anon, I'll twinge him by the ears. You musicians, play baloo.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No good George, let's ha' lachrimae.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Why this is it coney.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: It's all the better George: now sweet lamb, what story is that painted upon the cloth? the confutation of saint Paul?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: No lamb, that's Raph and Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Raph and Lucrece? which Raph? our Raph?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: No mouse, that was a Tartarian.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A Tartarian? well, I would the fiddlers had done, that we might see our Raph again.

div.head: Actus tertius,
Scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Come my dear dear, though we have lost our way,
We have not lost ourselves: are you not weary
With this nights wand'ring, broken from your rest?
And frighted with the terror that attends
The darkness of these wild unpeopled place?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: No my best friend, I cannot either fear,
Or entertain a weary thought, whilst you
(The end of all my full desires) stand by me.
Let them that lose their hopes, and live to languish
Amongst the number of forsaken lovers,
Tell the long weary steps, and number time,
Start at a shadow, and shrink up their blood,
Whilst I (Possessed with all content and quiet)
Thus take my pretty love, and thus embrace him.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: You have caught me luce, so fast, that whilst I live
I shall become your faithful prisoner,
And were these chains for ever. Come sit down,
And rest your body, too too delicate
For these disturbances; so, will you sleep?
Come, do not be more able than you are,
I know you are not skilful in these watches:
For women are no soldiers; be not nice,
But take it, sleep I say.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I cannot sleep,
Indeed I cannot friend.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Why then we'll sing,
And try how that will work upon our senses.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I'll sing, or say, or any thing but sleep.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Come little mermaid, rob me of my heart
With that enchanting voice.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: You mock me Jasper.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Tell me (Dearest) what is love?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: 'Tis a lightning from above,
'Tis an arrow, 'tis a fire,
'Tis a boy they call desire.
'Tis a smile
Doth beguile

sp.speaker: Ias.
sp.l: The poor hearts of men that prove.
Tell me more, are women true?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Some love change, and so do you.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Are they fair, and never kind?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes, when men turn with the wind.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Are they froward?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Ever towards,
Those that love, to love a new.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Dissemble it no more, I see the god
Of heavy sleep, lay on his heavy mace
Upon your eyelids.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I am very heavy.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Sleep, sleep, and quiet rest crown thy sweet thoughts:
Keep from her fair blood, distempers, startings,
Horrors, and fearful shapes: let all her dreams
Be joys, and chaste delights, embraces, wishes,
And such new pleasures, as the ravished soul
Gives to the senses. So, my charms have taken.
Keep her you powers divine, whilst I contemplate
Upon the wealth and beauty of her mind.
She is only fair, and constant: only kind,
And only to thee Jasper. O my joys!
Whither will you transport me? let not fullness
Of my poor buried hopes, come up together,
And overcharge my spirits: I am weak
Some say ( however ill) the sea and women
Are governed by the moon, both ebb and flow,
Both full of changes: yet to them that know,
And truly judge, these but opinions are,
And heresies to bring on pleasing war
between our tempers, that without these were
Both void of after-love, and present fear.
Which are the best of Cupid. O thou child!
Bred from despair, I dare not entertain thee,
Having a love without the faults of women,
And greater in her perfect goods then men:
Which to make good, and please myself the stronger,
Though certainly I am certain of her love,
I'll try her, that the world and memory
May sing to after times, her constancy.
Luce, Luce, awake.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Why do you fright me, friend,
With those distempered looks? what makes your sword
Drawn in your hand? who hath offended you?
I pre'chee Jasper sleep, thou art wild with watching.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Come make your way to heaven, and bid the world
(With all the villainies that stick upon it)
Farewell; you're for another life.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: O Jasper!
How have my tender years committed evil,
(Especially against the man I love)
Thus to be cropped untimely?

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Foolish girl,
Canst thou imagine I could love his daughter,
That flung me from my fortune into nothing?
Discharged me his service, shut the doors
Upon my poverty, and scorned my prayers,
Sending me, like a boat without a mast,
To sink or swim? Come, by this hand you die,
I must have life and blood to satisfy
Your father's wrongs.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Away George, away, raise the watch at Ludgate, and bring a mittimus from the justice for this desperate villain. Now I charge you gentlemen, see the King's peace kept. O my heart what a varlet's this to offer manslaughter upon the harmless gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I warrant thee (Sweet heart) we'll have him hampered.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: O Jasper! be not cruel,
If thou wilt kill me, mile and do it quickly.
And let not many deaths appear before me.
I am a woman made of fear and love,
A weak, weak woman, kill not with thy eyes,
They shoot me through and through. Strike I am ready,
And dying still I love thee.

div.stage: Enter merchant, Humphrey, and his men.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Whereabouts .

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: No more of this, now to myself again.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: There, there he stands with sword like martial knight
Drawn in his hand, therefore beware the fight
You that be wise: for were I good sir Bevis,
I would not stay his coming, by your leaves.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Sirrah, restore my daughter.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Sirrah, no.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Upon him then.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: So, down with him, down with him, down with him: cut him i'th leg boys, cut him i'th leg.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Come your ways minion, I'll provide a cage
For you, your grown so tame. Horse her away.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Truly I'm glad your forces have the day.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: They are gone, and I am hurt, my love is lost,
Never to get again. O me unhappy!
Bleed, bleed, and die, I cannot: o my folly!
Thou hast betrayed me. Hope where art thou fled?
Tell me if thou beest anywhere remaining.
Shall I but see my love again? O no!
She will not deign to look upon her butcher,
Nor is it fit she should; yet I must venture.
O chance, or fortune, or whate'er thou art
That men adore for powerful, hear my cry,
And let me loving, live; or losing, die.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Is a gone George?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I conie.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Marry and let him go (Sweet heart,) by the faith a my body 'a has put me into such a fright, that I tremble (As they say) as 'twere an aspen leaf: look a my little singer George, how it shakes: now i truth every member of my body is the worse for't.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p:
Come, hug in mine arms sweet mouse, he shall
not fright thee any more: alas mine own dear heart, how it quivers.

div.stage: Enter mistress Merrithought, Rafe, Michall, squire dwarf, host, and a tapster.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O Rafe, how dost thou Rafe? how hast thou slept tonight ? has the knight used thee well?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Peace Nell, let Rafe alone.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.l: Master, the reckoning is not paid.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Right courteous knight, who for the orde's sake
Which thou hast ta'en, hangest out the holy bell,
As I this flaming pestle bear about,
We render thanks to your puissant self,
Your beauteous lady, and your gentle squires,
For thus refreshing of our wearied limbs,
Stiffened with hard achievements in wild desert.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.l: Sir, there is twelve shillings to pay.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Thou merry squire Tapstero, thanks to thee,
For comforting our souls with double jug,
And if adventurous fortune prick thee forth,
Thou jovial squire, to follow feats of arms,
Take heed thou tender every lady's cause,
Every truery true knight, and every damsel fair fair;
But spill the blood of treacherous Sarazens,
And false enchanters, that with magic spells,
Have done to death full many a noble knight.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Thou valiant knight of the burning pestle, give ear to me, there is twelve shillings to pay, and as I am a true knight, I will not bate a penny.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: George, I pray thee tell me, must Rafe pay twelve shillings now?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: No Nell, no, nothing but the old knight is merry with Rafe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O is't nothing else? Rafe will be as merry as he.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Sir knight, this mirth of yours becomes you well,
But to requite this liberal courtesy,
If any of your squires will follow arms,
He shall receive from my heroic hand
a knighthood, by the virtue of this pestle.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Fair knight I thank you for noble offer,
Therefore gentle knight,
Twelve shillings you must pay, or I must cap you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Look George, did not I tell thee as much, the knight of the bell is in earnest, Raph shall not be beholding to him, give him his money George, and let him go snick-up.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Cap Raph? no; hold your hand sir knight of the bell, there's your money, have you any thing to say to Raph now? Cap Raph?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would you should know it, Raph has friends that will not suffer him to be capped for ten times so much, and ten times to the end of that, now take thy course Raph.

sp.speaker: M. Mer.
sp.p: Come Michael, thou and I will go home to thy father, he hath enough left to keep us a day or two, and we'll set fellows abroad to cry our purse and our casket, shall we Michael?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Ay, I pray mother, intruth my feet are full of chilblains with travelling.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Faith and those chilblains are a foul trouble, mistress Merrithought when your youth comes home let him rub all the soles of his feet, and the heels, and his ankles, with a mouse skin, or if none of your people can catch a mouse, when he goes to bed, let him roll his feet in the warm embers, and I warrant you he shall be well, and you may make him put his fingers between his toes and smell to them, it's very sovereign for his head if he be costive.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Master knight of the burning pestle, my son Michael and I, bid you farewell, I thank your worship heartily for your kindness.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Farewell fair lady and your tender squire,
If, pricking through these deserts, I do hear
Of any traitorous knight who through his guile,
Hath light upon your casket and your purse,
I will despoil him of them and restore them.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.l: I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Dwarf bear my shield, squire elevate my lance,
And now farewell you knight of holy bell.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Ay, i Raph, all is paid.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: But yet before I go, speak worthy knight,
If ought you do of sad adventures know,
Where errant knights may through his prowess win,
Eternal fame and free some gentle souls,
From endless bonds of steel and lingering pain.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Sirrah go to Nick the barber, and bid him prepare himself, as I told you before, quickly.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: I am gone sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sir knight, this wilderness affordeth none
But the great venture, where full many a knight
Hath tried his prowess and come off with shame,
And where I would not have you lose your life,
Against no man, but furious fiend of hell.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Speak on sir knight, tell what he is, and where,
For here I vow upon my blazing badge,
Never to blaze a day in quietness;
But bread and water will I only eat,
And the green herb and rock shall be my couch,
Till I have quelled that man, or beast, or fiend,
That works such damage to all errant knights.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Not far from hence, near to a craggy cliff,
At the North end of this distressed town,
There doth stand a lowly house
Ruggedly builded, and in it a cave,
In which an ugly giant now doth wone,
Cleped Barbaroso: in his hand
He shakes a naked lance of purest steel,
With sleeves turned up, and him before he wears,
A motley garment, to preserve his clothes
From blood of those knights which he massacres,
And ladies' gent: without his door doth hang
A copper balloon, on a prickant spear:
At which, no sooner gentle knights can knock,
But the shrill sound, fierce Barbaroso hears,
And rushing forth, brings in the errant knight,
And sets him down in an enchanted chair.
Then with an engine which he hath prepared,
with forty teeth, he claws his courtly crown,
Next makes him wink, and underneath his chin,
He plants a brazen piece of mighty board,
And knocks his bullets round about his cheeks,
Whilst with his fingers, and an instrument
With which he snaps his hair off, he doth fill
The wretch's ears with a most hideous noise.
Thus every knight adventurer he doth trim,
And now no creature dares encounter him.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: In god's name, I will fight him, kind sir,
Go but before me to this dismal cave,
Where this huge giant Barbaroso dwells,
And by that virtue that brave Rosicler,
That damned brood of ugly giants slew,
And Palmerin Frannarco overthrew:
I doubt not but to curb this traitor foul,
And to the devil send his guilty soul.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Brave sprighted knight, thus far I will perform.
This your request, I'll bring you with in sight
Of this most loathsome place, inhabited
By a more loathsome man: but dare not stay,
For his main force soopes all he sees away.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Saint George set on before, march squire and page.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: George, dost think Raph will confound the giant?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I hold my cap to a farthing he does: why Nell I saw him wrestle with the great Dutchman and hurl him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Faith and that Dutchman was a goodly man, if all things were answerable to his bigness, and yet they say there was a Scotchman higher than he, and that they two and a knight met, and saw one another for nothing, but of all the sights that ever were in London, since I was married, methinks the little child that was so fair grown about the members was the prettiest, that, and the hermaphrodite.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Nay by your leave Nell, Ninivy was better.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Niniveh, oh that was the story of Joan and the wall, was it not George?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Yes lamb.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Look George, here comes mistress Merrithought again, and I would have Raph come and fight with the giant, I tell you true, I long to see't.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Good mistress Merrithought be gone, I pray you for my sake, I pray you forbear a little, you shall have audience presently, I have a little business.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Mistress Merrithought if it please you to refrain your passion a little, till Raph have dispatch the giant out of the way we shall think ourselves much bound to you, I thank you good mistress Merrithought.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Boy, come hither, send away Raph and this whoreson giant quickly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: In good faith sir we cannot, you'll utterly spoil our play, and make it to be hissed, and it cost money, you will not suffer us to go on with our plot, I pray gentlemen rule him.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Let him come now and dispatch this, and I'll trouble you no more.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Will you give me your hand of that?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Give him thy hand George, do, and I'll kiss him, I warrant thee the youth means plainly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I'll send him to you presently.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I thank you little youth, faith the child hath a sweet breath George, but I think it be troubled with the worms, carduus benedictus and mare's milk were the only thing in the world for't, oh ralph's here George, God send thee good luck Raph.

div.stage: Enter Raph, host, squire, and dwarf.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Puissant knight yonder his mansion is,
Lo where the spear and copper basin are,
Behold that string on which hangs many a tooth,
Drawn from the gentle jaw of wand'ring knights,
I dare not stay to sound, he will appear.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: O faint not heart, Susan my lady dear,
The cobbler's maid in Milk-street, for whose sake,
I take these arms, oh let the thought of thee,
Carry thy knight through all adventurous deeds,
and in the honour of thy beauteous self,
May I destroy this monster Barbaroso,
Knock squire upon the basin till it break.
With the shrill strokes, or till the giant speak.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O George, the giant, the giant, now Raph for thy life.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.l: What fond unknowing wight is this? that dares
So rudely knock at Barbarossa's cell,
Where no man comes but leaves his fleece behind?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Ay, traitorous caitiff, who am sent by fate
To punish all the sad enormities
Thou hast committed against lady's gent
And errant knights, traitor to God and men:
Prepare thyself, this is the dismal hour
Appointed for thee, to give strict account
Of all thy beastly treacherous villainies.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.l: Foolhardy knight, full soon thou shalt aby
This fond reproach, thy body will I bang,
And lo upon that string thy teeth shall hang:
Prepare thyself, for dead soon shalt thou be,

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Saint George for me.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.p: Gargantua for me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: To him, Raph to him, hold up the giant, set out thy leg before Raph.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Falsify a blow Raph, falsify a blow, the giant lies open on the left side.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Bear't off, bear't of still; there boy, oh raphe's almost down, ralph's almost down.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Susan inspire me, now have up again.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Up, up, up, up, up, so Raph, down with him, down with him Raph.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Fetch him o'er the hip boy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
