sp.p: There boy, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, Raph.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: No Raph get all out of him first.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Presumptuous man, see to what desperate end
Thy treachery hath brought thee, the just gods,
Who never prosper those that do despise them,
For all the villainies which thou hast done
to knights and ladies, now have paid thee home
By my stiff arm, a knight adventurous,
But say vile wretch, before I send thy soul
To sad Avernus whether it must go,
What captives holdest thou in thy sable cave.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.l: Go in and free them all, thou hast the day.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Go squire and dwarf, search in this dreadful cave
And free the wretched prisoners from their bonds.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.l: I crave for mercy, as thou art a knight,
And scornest to spill the blood of those that beg.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Thou show'dst no mercy, nor shalt thou have any,
Prepare thyself for thou shalt surely die.

div.stage: Enter squire leading one winking, with a basin under his chin.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.l: Behold brave knight here is one prisoner,
Whom this wild man hath used as you see.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: This is the first wise word I heard the squire speak.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Speak what thou art, and how thou hast been used,
That that I may give condign punishment,

sp.speaker: 1. Kni.
sp.l: I am a knight that took my journey post
Northward from London, and in courteous wise,
This giant trained me to his loathsome den,
Under pretence of killing of the itch,
And all my body with a powder strewed,
That smarts and stings, and cut away my beard,
And my curled locks wherein were ribbons tied,
And with a water washed my tender eyes,
Whilst up and down about me still he skipped,
Whose virtue is, that till mine eyes be wiped
With a dry cloth, for this my foul disgrace,
I shall not dare to look a dog i'th' face.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Alas poor knight, relieve him Raph, relieve poor
Knights whilst you live.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: My trusty squire convey him to the town,
Where he may find relief, adieu fair knight,

div.stage: Enter dwarf leading one with a patch o'er his nose.

sp.speaker: Dwarf
sp.l: Puissant knight of the burning pestle hight,
see here another wretch, whom this foul beast
Hath scorched and scored in this inhuman wise.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Speak me thy name and eke thy place of birth,
And what hath been thy usage in this cave.

sp.speaker: 2. Knight.
sp.l: I am a knight, sir pock-hole is my name,
And by my birth I am a Londoner
Free by my copy, but my ancestors
Were Frenchmen all, and riding hard this way,
Upon a trotting horse, my bones did ache,
And I faint knight to ease my weary limbs,
Light at this cave, when straight this furious fiend,
With sharpest instrument of purest steel,
Did cut the gristle of my nose away,
And in the place this velvet plaster stands,
Relieve me gentle knight out of his hands.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Good Raph relieve sir pock-hole and send him away, for, intruth, his breath stinks,

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Convey him straight after the other knight,
Sir pock-hole fare you well.

sp.speaker: 2. Kni.
sp.l: Kind sir goodnight.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Deliver us.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Deliver us.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Hark George, what a woeful cry there is, I think some woman lies in there.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Deliver us.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Deliver us.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: What ghastly noise is this? speak Barbarose,
Or by this blazing steel thy head goes off.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.l: Prisoners of mine whom I in diet keep,
Send lower down into the cave,
And in a tub that's heated smoking hot,
There may they find them and deliver them,

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Run squire and dwarf, deliver them with speed.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: But will not Raph kill this giant, surely I am afeard if he let him go he will do as much hurt, as ever he did.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Not so mouse neither, if he could convert him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I George if he could convert him, but a giant is not so soon converted as one of us ordinary people: there's a pretty tale of a witch, that had the devil's mark about her, God bless us, that had a giant to her son, that was called Lob-lie-by-the-fire, didst never here it George?

div.stage: Enter squire leading a man with a glass of lotion in his hand, and the dwarf leading a woman, with diet-bread and drink.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Peace Nell, here comes the prisoners.

sp.speaker: Dwarf
sp.l: Here be these pined wretches, manful knight,
That for these six weeks have not seen a wight.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Deliver what you are, and how you came
To this sad cave, and what your usage was?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I am an errant knight that followed arms,
With spear and shield, and in my tender years
I stricken was with Cupid's fiery shaft,
And fell in love with this my lady dear,
And stole her from her friends in Turnbull-street,
And bore her up and down from town to town,
Where we did eat and drink and music hear,
Till at the length, at this unhappy town
We did arrive, and coming to this cave
This beast us caught and put us in a tub,
Where we this two months sweat, and should have done
Another month if you had not relieved us.

sp.speaker: Vvom.
sp.l: This bread and water hath our diet been,
Together with a rib cut from a neck
Of burned mutton, hard hath been our fare,
Release us from this ugly giants snare.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: This hath been all the food we have received,
But only twice a day for novelty,
He gave a spoonful of this hearty broth,
To each of us, through this same slender quill.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: From this infernal monster you shall go,
That useth knights and gentle ladies so,
Convey them hence.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Coney, I can tell thee the gentlemen like Rafe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I George, I see it well enough. Gentlemen I thank you all heartily for gracing my man Rafe, and I promise you you shall see him oftener.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.l: Mercy great knight, I do recant my ill,
And henceforth never gentle blood will spill.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: I give thee mercy, but yet shalt thou swear
Upon my burning pestle, to perform
Thy promise uttered.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.l: I swear and kiss.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Depart then, and amend.
sp.p: Come squire and dwarf, the sun grows towards his set, and we have many more adventures yet.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Now Rafe is in this humour, I know he would ha' beaten all the boys in the house if they had been set on him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I George, but it is well as it is, I warrant you the gentlemen do consider what it is to overthrow a giant: but look George, here comes mistress Merrithought and her son Michael; now you are welcome mistress merry - thought, now Rafe has done you may go on.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Mick my boy?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: I forsooth mother.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Be merry Mick we are at home now; where I warrant you, you shall find the house flung out at the windows: hark, heigh dogs, heigh, this is the old world i'faith with my husband, if I get in among 'em, I'll play 'em such a lesson, that they shall have little list to come scraping hither, again. Why master Merrithought, husband, Charles Merrithought.

sp.speaker: Old Merri. within.
sp.p:
If you will sing and dance, and laugh, and hollow, and laugh again, and then cry there boys, there: why than
One, two, three, and four,
We shall be merry within this hour.

sp.speaker: Mistress Merri.
sp.p:
Why Charles, do you not know your
own natural wife? I say, open the door, and turn me out those mangy companions; 'tis more than time that they were fellow and fellow like with you: you are a gentleman Charles, and an old man, and father of two children; and I myself (Though I say it) by my mother's side, niece to a worshipful gentleman, and a conductor, ha has been three times in his majesty's service at Chester, and is now the fourth time, God bless him, and his charge upon his journey.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: Go from my window, love, go;
Go from my window my dear,
The wind and the rain will drive you back again,
You cannot he lodged here.
sp.p: Hark you mistress Merrithought, you that walk upon adventures, and forsake your husband, because he sings with never a penny in his purse; what shall I think myself the worse? Faith no, I'll be merry.
You come not here, here's none but lads of mettle, lives of a hundred years, and onwards, care never drunk their bloods, nor want made 'em warble.
Hey-ho, my heart is heavy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mer.
sp.p: Why Mr. Merrithought, what am I that you should laugh me to scorn thus abruptly? am I not your fellow-feeler (As we may say) in all our miseries? your comforter in health and sickness? have I not brought you children? are they not like you Charles? look upon thine own image hard-hearted man; and yet for all this —

sp.speaker: Old Mer. within.
sp.p: Begone, begone, my juggy, my puggy, begone my love, my dear.
The weather is warm, 'twill do thee no harm, thou canst not be lodged here.
Be merry boys, some light music, and more wine.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: He's not in earnest, I hope George, is he?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: What if he be, sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Marry if he be George, I'll make bold to tell him he's an ingrate old man, to use his bedfellow so scurvily.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: What how does he use her honey?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Marry come up sir saucebox, I think you'll take his part, will you not? Lord how hot you are grown: you are a fine man an you had a fine dog, it becomes you sweetly.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Nay prithee Nell chide not: for as I am an honest man, and a true Christian grocer, I do not like his doings.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I cry you mercy then George; you know we are all frail, and full of infirmities. D'ye hear mr. Merrithought, may I crave a word with you?

sp.speaker: Old Mer within.
sp.p: Strike up lively lads.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I had not thought in truth, Mr. Merrithought, that a man of your age and discretion (As I may say) being a gentleman, and therefore known by your gentle conditions, could have used so little respect to the weakness of his wife: for your wife is your own flesh, the staff of your age, your yoke-fellow, with whose help you draw through the mire of this transitory world: nay, she's your own rib. And again —

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: I come not hither for thee to teach,
I have no pulpit for thee to preach,
I would thou hadst kissed me under the breech,
As thou art a lady gay.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Marry with a vengeance.
sp.p: I am heartily sorry for the poor gentlewoman: but if I were thy wife, i'faith graybeard, i'faith —

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I prithee sweet honeysuckle, be content.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Give me such words that am a gentlewoman born, hang him hoary rascal. Get me some drink George, I am almost molten with fretting: now beshrew his knave's heart for it.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: Play me a light lavalto: come, be frolic, fill the good fellow's wine.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Why Mr. Merrithought, are you disposed to make me wait here: you'll open I hope, I'll fetch them that shall open else.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: Good woman if you will sing I'll give you something, if not -

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: You are no love for me Marg'ret, I am no love for you.
Come aloft boys, aloft.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Now a churl's fart in your teeth sir: come Mick, we'll not trouble him, 'a shall not ding us i'th teeth with his bread and his broth: that he shall not: come boy, I'll provide for thee, I warrant thee: we'll go to master Venterwel's the merchant, I'll get his letter to mine host of the bell in Waltham, there I'll place thee with the tapster; will not that do well for thee Mick? and let me alone for that old cuckoldly knave your father, I'll use him in his kind, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Come George, where's the beer?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Here love.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: This old fornicating fellow will not out of my mind yet; gentlemen, I'll begin to you all, and I desire more of your acquaintance, with all my heart. Fill the gentlemen some beer George.

div.head: Actus quartus,
Scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Look George, the little boy's come again, methinks he looks something like the prince of orange in his long stocking, if he had a little harness about his neck. George I will have him dance fading; fading is a fine jig I'll assure you gentlemen: begin brother, now a caper's sweet heart, now a turn a'th toe, and then tumble: cannot you tumble youth?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No indeed forsooth:

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nor eat fire?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why then I thank you heartily, there's two pence to buy you points withal.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.p: There boy, deliver this: but do it well. Hast thou provided me four lusty fellows?
sp.l: Able to carry me? and art thou perfect
In all thy business?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir, you need not fear,
I have my lesson here, and cannot miss it:
The men are ready for you, and what else
Pertains to this employment.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: There my boy,
Take it, but buy no land.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Faith sir 'twere rare
To see so young a purchaser: I fly,
And on my wings carry your destiny.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Go, and be happy. Now my latest hope
Forsake me not, but fling thy anchor out,
And let it hold: stand fixed thou rolling stone,
Till I enjoy my dearest: hear me all
You powers that rule in men celestial.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Go thy ways, thou art as crooked a sprig as ever grew in London; I warrant him he'll come to some naughty end or other: for his looks say no less: besides, his father (You know George) is none of the best, you heard him take me up like a flirt Gill, and sing bawdy songs upon me: but i'faith if I live George —

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Let me alone sweetheart, I have a trick in my head shall lodge him in the arches for one year, and make him sing peocani, ere I leave him, and yet he shall never know who hurt him neither.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Do my good George, do.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: What shall we have Rafe do now boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You shall have what you will sir.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Why so sir, go and fetch me him then, and let the sophy of Persia come and christen him a child.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Believe me sir, that will not do so well, 'tis stale, it has been had before at the red bull.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: George let Rafe travel over great hills, and let him be very weary, and come to the King of Cracovia's house, covered with velvet, and there let the King's daughter stand in her window all in beaten gold, combing her golden locks with a comb of ivory, and let her spy Rafe, and fall in love with him, and come down to him, and carry him into her father's house, and then let Rafe talk with her.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Well said Nell, it shall be so: boy let's have't done quickly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, if you will imagine all this to be done already, you shall hear them talk together: but we cannot present a house covered with black velvet, and a lady in beaten gold.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Sir boy, let's have't as you can then.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Besides it will show ill-favouredly to have a grocer's prentice to court a King's daughter.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Will it so sir? you are well read in histories: I pray you what was sir Dagonet? was not he prentice to a grocer in London? read the play of the four prentices of London, where they toss their pikes so: I pray you fetch him in sir, fetch him in.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It shall be done, it is not our fault gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Now we shall see fine doings I warrant tee George. O here they come; how prettily the King of Cracuioa's daughter is dressed.

div.stage: Enter Rafe and the lady, squire and dwarf.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I Nell, it is the fashion of that country, I warrant tee.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Welcome sir knight unto my father's court.
King of Moldavia, unto me Pompiona
His daughter dear: but sure you do not like
Your entertainment, that will stay with us
No longer but a night.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Damsel right fair,
I am on many sad adventures bound,
That call me forth into the wilderness:
Besides, my horse's back is something galed,
Which will enforce me ride a sober pace.
But many thanks (Fair lady) be to you,
For using errant knight with courtesy.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But say (Brave knight) what is your name and birth?

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: My name is Rafe, I am an English man,
As true as steel, a hearty Englishman,
And prentice to a grocer in the strand,
By deed indent, of which I have one part:
But fortune calling me to follow arms,
On me this holy order I did take,
Of burning pestle, which in all men's eyes,
I bear, confounding ladies' enemies.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Oft have I heard of your brave countrymen,
And fertile soil, and store of wholesome food:
My father oft will tell me of a drink
In England found, and nipitato called.
Which driveth all the sorrow from your hearts.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Lady 'tis true, you need not lay your lips
To better nipitato than there is.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And of a wildfowl he will often speak,
Which powdered beef and mustard called is:
For there have been great wars 'twixt us and you,
But truly Rafe, it was not long of me.
Tell me then Rafe, could you contented be,
To wear a lady's favour in your shield?

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: I am a knight of religious order,
And will not wear a favour of a lady's
That trusts in Antichrist, and false traditions.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Well said Rafe, convert her if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Besides, I have a lady of my own
In merry England, for whose virtuous sake
I took these arms, and Susan is her name,
A cobbler's maid in Milk-street, whom I vow
Ne'er to forsake, whilst life and pestle last.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Happy that cobbling dame, who ere she be,
That for her own (Dear Rafe) hath gotten thee.
Unhappy I, that ne'er shall see the day
To see thee more, that bearest my heart away.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Lady farewell, I needs must take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Hard-hearted Rafe, that ladies dost deceive.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Hark thee Rafe, there's money for thee; give something in the King of Cracovia's house, be not beholding to him.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Lady before I go, I must remember
Your father's officers, who truth to tell,
Have been about me very diligent.
Hold up thy snowy hand thou princely maid,
There's twelve pence for your father's chamberlain,
and another shilling for his cook,
For by my troth the goose was roasted well.
And twelvepence for your father's horsekeeper,
For 'nointing my horse back; and for his butter
There is another shilling. To the maid
That washed my boot-hose, there's an English groat;
And two pence to the boy that wiped my boots:
And last, fair lady, there is for yourself
Three pence to buy you pins at Bumbo fair.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Full many thanks, and I will keep them safe
Till all the heads be off, for thy sake Rafe.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Advance my squire and dwarf, I cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Thou killest my heart in parting thus away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I commend Rafe yet that he will not stoop to a Craconjan, there's properer women in London than any are there iwis. But here comes master Humphrey and his love again now George.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I coney, peace.

div.stage: Enter merchant, Humphrey, Luce and a boy.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Go get you up, I will not be entreated.
And gossip mine, I'll keep you sure hereafter
From gadding out again with boys and unthrifts,
Come, they are women's tears, I know your fashion.
Go sirrah, lock her in, and keep the key,
Safe as you love your life. Now my son Humphrey,
You may both rest assured of my love
In this, and reap your own desire.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: I see this love you speak of, through your daughter,
Although the hole be little; and hereafter
Will yield the like in all I may, or can,
Fitting a christian, and a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: I do believe you (My good son) and thank you:
For 'twere an impudence to think you flattered.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: It were indeed, but shall I tell you why,
I have been beaten twice about the lie.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Well son, no more of compliment, my daughter
Is yours again; appoint the time, and take her,
we'll have no stealing for it, I myself
And some few of our friends will see you married.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: I would you would i'faith, for be it known
I ever was afraid to lie alone.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Some three days hence then.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Three days, let me see,
'Tis somewhat of the most, yet I agree,
Because I mean against the appointed day,
To visit all my friends in new array.

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Sir, there's a gentlewoman without would speak with your worship.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: What is she?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir I asked her not.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: Bid her come in.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Peace be to your worship, I come as a poor suitor to you sir, in the behalf of this child.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: Are you not wife to Merrithought?

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Yes truly, would I had ne'er seen his eyes, ha has undone me and himself and his children, and there he lives at home and sings, and hoights, and revels among his drunken companions, but, I warrant you, where to get a penny to put bread in his mouth, he knows not: and therefore if it like your worship, I would entreat your letter, to the honest host of the bell in Waltham, that I may place my child under the protection of his tapster, in some settled course of life.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: I'm glad the heavens have heard my prayers: thy husband
When I was ripe in sorrows laughed at me,
Thy son like an unthankful wretch, I having
Redeemed him from his fall and made him mine,
To show his love again, first stole my daughter,
Then wronged this gentleman, and last of all,
Gave me that grief, had almost brought me down
Unto my grave, had not a stronger hand
Relieved my sorrows, go, and weep, as I did
And be unpitied, for I here profess
An everlasting hate to all thy name.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p:
Will you so sir, how say you by that? come
Mick, let him keep his wind to cool his porridge, we'll go to thy nurse's mick, she knits silk stockings boy, and we'll knit too boy, and be beholding to none of them all.

div.stage: Enter a boy with a letter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir, I take it you are the master of this house.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: How then boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Then to yourself sir comes this letter.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: From whom my pretty boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: From him that was your servant, but no more
Shall that name ever be, for he is dead,
Grief of your purchased anger broke his heart,
I saw him die, and from his hand received
This paper, with a charge to bring it hither,
Read it, and satisfy yourself in all.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: Sir, that I have wronged your love, I must confess, in which I have purchased to myself, besides mine own undoing, the ill opinion of my friends, let not your anger, good sir, out live me, but suffer me to rest in peace with your forgiveness; let my body (If a dying man may so much prevails with you) be brought to your daughter, that she may truly know my hate flames are now buried, and, withal, receive a testimony of the zeal I bore her virtue: farewell for ever, and be ever happy. Jasper.
sp.l: God's hand is great in this, I do for give him,
Yet I am glad he's quiet, where I hope
He will not bite again: boy bring the body
And let him have his will, if that be all.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: 'Tis here without sir.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: So sir, if you please
You may conduct it in, I do not fear it.

sp.speaker: Hump.
sp.l: I'll be your usher boy, for though I say it,
He owed me something once, and well did pay it.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: If there be any punishment inflicted
Upon the miserable, more than yet I feel,
Let it together cease me, and at once
press down my soul, I cannot bear the pain
Of these delaying tortures: thou then art
The end of all, and the sweet rest of all;
Come, come o death, bring me to thy peace,
And blot out all the memory I nourish
Both of my father and my cruel friend.
O wretched maid still living to be wretched,
To be a say to fortune in her changes,
And grow to number times and woes together,
How happy had I been, if being born
My grave had been my cradle?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.l: By your leave
Young mistress, here's a boy hath brought a coffin,
What 'a would say I know not, but your father
Charged me to give you notice, here they come.

div.stage: Enter two bearing a coffin, Jasper in it.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: For me I hoped 'tis come, and 'tis most welcome.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Fair mistress let me not add greater grief
To that great store you have already; Jasper
That whilst he lived was yours, now dead,
And here enclosed, commanded me to bring
His body hither, and to crave a tear
From those fair eyes, though he deserved not pity,
To deck his funeral, for so he bid me
Tell her for whom he died.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: He shall have many:
Good friends depart a little, whilst I take
My leave of this dead man, that once I loved:
Hold, yet a little, life and then I give thee
To thy first heavenly being; oh my friend!
Hast thou deceived me thus, and got before me?
I shall not long be after, but believe me,
Thou wert too cruel Jasper 'gainst thyself,
In punishing the fault, I could have pardoned,
With so untimely death; thou didst not wrong me,
But ever were't most kind, most true, most loving;
And I the most unkind, most false, most cruel.
Didst thou but ask a tear? I'll give thee all,
even all my eyes can pour down, all my sighs
And all myself, before thou goest from me
There are but sparing rites: but if thy soul
Be yet about this place, and can behold
And see what I prepare to deck thee with,
It shall go up, born on the wings of peace
And satisfied: first will I sing thy dirge,
Then kiss thy pale lips, and then die myself,
And fill one coffin and one grave together.

lg.l: Come you whose loves are dead,
And whiles I sing
Weep and wring
Every hand and every head,
Bind with cypress and sad ewe,
Ribbons black, and candles blew,
For him that was of men most true.
Come with heavy mourning,
And on his grave
Let him have
Sacrifice of sighs and groaning,
Let him have fair flowers enough,
White and purple, green and yellow,
For him that was of men most true.

sp.l: Thou sable cloth, said cover of my joys
I lift thee up, and thus I meet with death.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: And thus you meet the living

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Save me heaven.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Nay do not fly me fair, I am no spirit,
Look better on me, do you know me yet?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O thou dear shadow of my friend.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Dear substance,
I swear I am no shadow, feel my hand,
It is the same it was, I am your jasper,
Your Jasper that's yet living, and yet loving,
Pardon my rash attempt, my foolish proof
I put in practice of your constancy,
For sooner should my sword have drunk my blood,
And set my soul at liberty, then drawn
The least drop from that body; for which boldness
Doom me to any thing: if death I take it
And willingly.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: This death I'll give you for it,
So, now I am satisfied: you are no spirit,
But my own truest, truest, truest friend,
Why do you come thus to me.

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.l: First to see you,
Than to convey you hence.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: It cannot be,
For I am locked up here and watched at all hours,
That 'tis impossible for me to scape.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Nothing more possible, within this coffin
Do you convey yourself, let me alone,
I have the wits of twenty men about me,
Only I crave the shelter of your closet
A little, and then fear me not; creep in
That they may presently convey you hence:
Fear nothing dearest love, I'll be your second,
Lie close, so, all goes well yet; boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: At hand sir.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Convey away the coffin, and be wary.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: 'Tis done already.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Now must I go conjure.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: Boy, boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Your servant sir.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: Do me this kindness boy, hold here's a crown: before thou bury the body of this fellow, carry it to his old merry father, and salute him from me, and bid him sing, he hath cause.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: And then bring me word what tune he is in, and have another crown: but do it truly.
sp.l: I have fitted him a bargain, now, will vex him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: God bless your worship's health sir.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: Farewell boy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ah old Merrithought, art thou there again, let's here some of thy songs.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: Who can sing a merrier note,
Than he that cannot change a groat?
sp.p: Not a denier left, and yet my heart leaps, I do wonder yet, as old as I am, that any man will follow a trade, or serve, that may sing and laugh, and walk the streets, my wife and both my sons are I know not where, I have nothing left, nor know I how to come by meat to supper, yet am I merry still; for I know I shall find it upon the table at six o'clock , therefore hang thought.
sp.l: I would not be a servingman to carry the cloak-bag still,
Nor would I be a falconer the greedy hawks to fill.
But I would be in a good house, and have a good master too.
But I would eat and drink of the best, and no work would I do.
sp.p: This is it that keeps life and soul together, mirth, this is the philosopher's stone that they write so much on, that keeps a man ever young.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, they say they know all your money is gone, and they will trust you for no more drink.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: Will they not? let am choose, the best is I have mirth at home, and need not send abroad for that, let them keep their drink to themselves.
sp.l: For Jillian of Berry she dwells on a hill,
And she hath good beer and ale to sell.
And of good fellows she thinks no ill,
And thither will we go now, now, now, now, and thither
Will we go now.
And when you have made a little stay,
You need not ask what is to pay,
But kiss your hostess and go your way, and thither, etc.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.p: Sir, I can get no bread for supper.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: Hang bread and supper, let's preserve our mirth, and we shall never feel hunger, I'll warrant you, let's have a càtch, boy follow me, come sing this catch.
Ho, ho, nobody at home, meat, nor drink, nor money ha' we none, fill the pot eedy, never more need I.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: So boys enough, follow me, let's change our place and we shall laugh afresh.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Let him go George, 'a shall not have any countenance from us, nor a good word from any i'th' company, if I may strike stroke in't.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: No more a sha'not love; but Nell I will have Raph do a very notable matter now, to the eternal honour and glory of all grocers, sirrah you there boy, can none of you hear?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Let Raph come out on May-day in the morning and speak upon a conduit with all his scarves about him, and his feathers and his rings and his knacks.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why sir you do not think of our plot, what will become of that then?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Why sir, I care not what become on't, I'll have him come out, or I'll fetch him out myself, I'll have something done in honour of the city, besides, he hath been long enough upon adventures, bring him out quickly, or if I come in amongst you —

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Well sir he shall come out, but if our play miscarry, sir you are like to pay for't.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Bring him away then.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: This will be brave i'faith, George shall not he dance the morris too for the credit of the strand.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: No sweet heart it will be too much for the boy, o there he is Nell, he's reasonable well in reparel, but he has not rings enough.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: London, to thee I do present the merry month of May
let each true subject be content to hear me what I say:
For from the top of conduit head, as plainly may appear,
I will both tell my name to you and wherefore I came here.
My name is Raph, by due descent, though not ignoble I,
Yet far inferior to the flock of gracious grocery.
And by the common-council, of my fellows in the strand,
With guilded staff, and crossed scarf, the may-lord here I stand.
Rejoice, o English hearts, rejoice, rejoice o lovers dear,
Rejoice o city, town, and country, rejoice eke every shire;
For now the fragrant flowers do spring and sprout in seemly sort,
The little birds do sit and sing, the lambs do make fine sport.
And now the Burchin tree doth bud that makes the school boy cry
The morris rings while hobby-horse doth foot it feateously:
The lords and ladies now abroad for their disport and play,
Do kiss sometimes upon the grass, and sometimes in the hey.
Now butter with a leaf of sage is good to purge the blood,
Fly Venus and phlebotomy for they are neither good.
Now little fish on tender stone, begin to cast their bellies,
And sluggish snails, that erst were mute, do creep out of their shells
The rumbling rivers now do warm for little boys to paddle,
The sturdy steed, now goes to grass, and up they hang his saddle.
The heavy heart, the bellowing buck, the rascal and the pricket,
Are now among the yeoman's pease, and leave the fearful thicket.
And be like them, o you, I say, of this same noble town,
And lift aloft your velvet heads, and slipping of your gown:
With bells on legs, and napkins clean unto your shoulders tide,
With scarves and garters as you please, and heigh for our town cried
March out and show your willing minds by twenty and by twenty,
To Hogsdon or to Newington, where ale and cakes are plenty:
And let it ne'er be said, for shame, that we the youths of London,
Lay thrumming of our caps at home, and left our custom undone.
Up then, I say, both young and old, both man and maid a-maying
With drums and guns that bounce aloud, and merry taber playing.
Which to prolong, God save our King, and send his country peace
And root out treason from the land, and so, my friends I cease.

div.head: Actus 5.
Scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: I will have no great store of company at the wedding, a couple of neighbours and their wives, and we will have a capon in stewed broth, with marrow, and a good piece of beef, stuck with rosemary.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Forbear thy pains fond man, it is too late.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Heaven bless me: Jasper?

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Ay, I am his ghost
Whom thou hast injured for his constant love:
Fond worldly wretch, who dost not understand
In death that true hearts cannot parted be.
First know thy daughter is quite born away,
On wings of angels, through the liquid air,
To far out of thy reach, and never more
Shalt thou behold her face: but she and I
Will in another world enjoy our loves,
Where neither father's anger, poverty,
Nor any cross that troubles earthly men
Shall make us sever our united hearts.
And never shalt thou sit, or be alone
In any place, but I will visit thee
With ghastly looks, and put into thy mind
The great offences which thou didst to me.
When thou art at thy table with thy friends
Merry in heart, and filled with swelling wine,
I'll come in midst of all thy pride and mirth,
Invisible to all men but thyself,
And whisper such a sad tale in thine ear,
Shall make thee let the cup fall from thy hand,
And stand as mute and pale as death itself.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Forgive me Jasper; oh! what might I do?
Tell me, to satisfy thy trobled ghost?

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: There is no means, too late thou thinkst of this.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: But tell me what were best for me to do?

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Repent thy deed, and satisfy my father,
And beat fond Humphrey out of thy doors,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Look George, his very ghost would have folks beaten.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Father, my bride is gone, fair mistress Luce,
My soul's the fount of vengeance, mischief's sluice.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Hence fool out of my sight, with thy fond passion
Thou hast undone me.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Hold my father dear,
For Luce thy daughter's sake, that had no peer.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Thy father fool? there's some blows more, begone.
Jasper, I hope thy ghost be well appeased,
To see thy will performed, now will I go
To satisfy thy father for thy wrongs.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: What shall I do? I have been beaten twice,
And mistress Luce is gone? help me device:
Since my true-love is gone, I never more,
Whilst I do live, upon the sky will pore;
But in the dark will wear out my shoe-soles
In passion, in saint faith's church under Paul's.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: George call Rafe hither, if you love me call Rafe hither, I have the bravest thing for him to do George; prithee call him quickly.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Rafe, why Rafe boy.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Come hither Rafe, come to thy mistress boy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Rafe I would have thee call all the youths together in battle-ray, with drums, and guns, and flags, and march to mile end in pompous fashion, and there exhort your soldiers to be merry and wise, and to keep their beards from burning Rafe, and then skirmish, and let your flags fly, and cry kill, kill, kill: my husband shall lend you his jerkin Rafe, and there's a scarf; for the rest, the house shall furnish you,
and we'll pay for't: do it bravely Rafe, and think before whom you perform, and what person you represent.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: I warrant you mistress if I do it not for the honour of the city, and the credit of my master, let me never hope for freedom.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: 'Tis well spoken i'faith; go thy ways, thou art a spark indeed.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Rafe, Rafe, double your files bravely Rafe.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: I warrant you sir.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Let him look narrowly to his service, I shall take him else, I was there myself a pikeman once in the hottest of the day, wench; had my feather shot sheer away, the fringe of my pike burned off with powder, my pate broken with a scouring-stick, and yet I thank God I am here.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Hark George the drums.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Ran, tan, tan, tan; ran, tan: oh wench an thou hadst but seen little Ned of Algate, drum Ned, how he made it roar again, and laid on like a tyrant: and then stroke softly till the ward came up, and then thundered again, and together we go: sa, sa, sa, bounce quoth the guns: courage my hearts, quoth the captains: saint George, quoth the pikemen; and withal here they lay, and there they lay: and yet for all this I am here wench.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Be thankful for it George, for indeed 'tis wonderful.

div.stage: Enter Rafe and his company with drums and colours.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: March fair my hearts, lieutenant beat the rear up: ancient, let your colours fly; but have a great care of the butcher's hooks at Whitechapel, they have been the death of many a fair ancient. Open your files that I may take a view both of your persons and munition: sergeant call a muster.

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: A stand, William Hamerton pewterer.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Here captain.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: A corslet, and a Spanish pike; 'tis well, can you shake it with a terror?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I hope so captain.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Charge upon me, 'tis with the weakest: put more strength William Hammerton, more strength: as you were again. Proceed sergeant.

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: George green-goose, poulterer?

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Let me see your piece neighbour green-goose, when was she shot in?

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: And like you master captain, I made a shot even now, partly to scour her, and partly for audacity.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: It should seem so certainly, for her breath is yet inflamed: besides, there is a main fault in the touchhole, it runs, and stinketh; and I tell you moreover, and believe it: ten such touch-holes would breed the pox in the army. Get you a feather, neighbour, get you a feather, sweet oil, and paper, and your piece may do well enough yet. Where's your powder?

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: What in a paper? As I am a soldier, and gentleman, it craves a martial court: you ought to die for't. Where's your horn? answer me to that.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: An't like you sir, I was oblivious.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: It likes me not you should be so; 'tis a shame for you, and a scandal to all our neighbours, being a man of worth and estimation, to leave your horn behind you: I am afraid 'twill breed example. But let me tell you no more on't; stand, till I view you all. What's become o'th nose of your flask?

sp.speaker: 1. Soldier.
sp.p: Indeed la captain, 'twas blown away with powder.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Put on a new one at the city's charge. Where's the stone of this piece?

sp.speaker: 2. Soldier.
sp.p: The drummer took it out to light tobacco.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p:
'Tis a fault my friend, put it in again: you want a nose, and you a stone; sergeant, take a note on't, for I mean to stop it in the pay. Remove and march, soft and
fair gentlemen, soft and fair: double your files, as you were, faces about. Now you with the sodden face, keep in there: look to your match sirrah, it will be in your fellow's flask anon. So, make a crescent now, advance your pikes, stand and give ear. Gentlemen, countrymen, friends, and my fellow-soldiers, I have brought you this day from the shops of security, and the counters of content, to measure out in these furious fields, honour by the ell; and prowess by the pound: let it not, o let it not, I say, be told hereafter, the noble issue of this city fainted: but bear yourselves in this fair action, like men, valiant men, and freemen; fear not the face of the enemy, nor the noise of the guns: for believe me brothers, the rude rumbling of a brewer's car is far more terrible, of which you have a daily experience: neither let the stink of powder offend you, since a more valiant stink is nightly with you. To a resolved mind, his home is everywhere : I speak not this to take away the hope of your return; for you shall see (I do not doubt it) and that very shortly, your loving wives again, and your sweet children, whose care doth bear you company in baskets. Remember then whose cause you have in hand, and like a sort of trueborn scavengers, scour me this famous realm of enemies. I have no more to say but this: stand to your tacklings lads, and show to the world you can as well brandish a sword, as shake an apron. Saint George and on my hearts.

div.stage: Omnes. st. George, st. George. exeunt

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: 'Twas well done Rafe, I'll send thee a cold capon a field, and a bottle of march-beer; and it may be, come myself to see thee.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Nell, the boy has deceived me much, I did not think it had been in him: he has performed such a matter wench, that if I live, next year I'll have him captain of the galley-foist, or I'll want my will.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p:
Yet I thank God, I break not a wrinkle more than I had, not a stoop boyce: care live with cats, I defy thee, my heart is as sound as an oak; and though I want drink
to wet my whistle, I can sing:
Come no more there boys, come no more there:
For we shall never whilst we live, come any more there.

div.stage: Enter a boy with a coffin.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Oldmer.
sp.p: It's a brave boy: canst thou sing?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes sir, I can sing, but 'tis not so necessary at this time.

sp.speaker: Old Merri.
sp.p: Sing we, and chant it, whilst love doth grant it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, sir, if you knew what I have brought you, you would have little list to sing.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: O the mimon round, full long long I have thee sought,
And now I have thee found, and what hast thou here brought?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A coffin sir, and your dead son Jasper in it.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: Dead? why farewell he:
Thou wast a bonny boy, and I did love thee.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Then I pray you sir do so still.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: Jasper's ghost? thou art welcome from Stygian lake so soon,
Declare to me what wondrous things in Pluto's court are done.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: By my troth sir, I ne'er came there, 'tis too hot for me sir.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: A merry ghost, a very merry ghost.
And where is your true-love? O where is yours?

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Marry look you sir.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: Ah ha! Art thou good at that i'faith?
With heigh trixie terlery-whiskin, the world it runs on wheels,
When the young man's — up goes the maiden's heels.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: What Mr. Merrithought, will you not let's in? what do you think shall become of us?

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: What voice is that that calleth at our door?

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p:
You know me well enough, I am sure I have not
been such a stranger to you.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: And some they whistled, and some they sung, heigh down, down: and some did loudly say, ever as the lord Barnet's horn blew, away Musgrave, away.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: You will not have us starve here, will you Mr. Merrithought?

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.p: Nay good sir be persuaded, she is my mother: if her offences have been great against you, let your own love remember she is yours, and so forgive her.

sp.speaker: Luce
sp.p: Good Mr. Merrithought let me entreat you, I will not be denied.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Why Mr. Merrithought, will you be a vexed thing still?

sp.speaker: Old. Mer.
sp.p: Woman I take you to my love again, but you shall sing before you enter: therefore dispatch your song, and so come in.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.l: Well, you must have your will when all's done.
Mick what song canst thou sing boy?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: I can sing none forsooth, but a lady's daughter of Paris properly.

sp.speaker: Mistress Mer.
sp.p: Song. It was, a lady's daughter, etc.

sp.speaker: Old. Mer.
sp.l: Come, you're welcome home again.
If such danger be in playing, and jest must to earnest turn,
You shall go no more a-maying.

sp.speaker: Marchant within.
sp.l: Are you within sir, master Merrithought?

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.p: It is my master's voice, good sir go hold him in talk whilst we convey ourselves into some inward room.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: What are you? are you merry? you must be very merry if you enter.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: I am sir.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: Sing then.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: Nay good sir open to me.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: Sing, I say, or by the merry heart you come not in.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Well sir, I'll sing.
Fortune my fee, etc.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: You are welcome sir, you are welcome, you see your entertainment, pray you be merry.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: O Mr. Merrithought, I am come to ask you
forgiveness for the wrongs I offered you,
And your most virtuous son, they're infinite,
Yet my contrition shall be more than they.
I do confess my hardness broke his heart,
For which, just heaven hath given me punishment
More than my age can carry, his wand'ring spirit
Not yet at rest, pursues me everywhere ,
Crying, I'll haunt thee for thy cruelty.
My daughter she is gone, I know not how,
Taken invisible, and whether living,
Or in grave, 'tis yet uncertain to me.
O master Merrithought, these are the weights,
Will sink me to my grave, forgive me sir.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: Why sir, I do forgive you, and be merry,
And if the wag, in's life time, played the knave,
Can you forgive him too?

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: Withal my heart sir.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: Speak it again, and heartily.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.l: I do sir,
Now by my soul I do.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.l: With that came out his paramour,
She was as white as the lily flower,
Heigh troule trolly-lolly .
With that came out her own dear knight,
He was as true as ever did fight. Etc.
sp.p: Sir, if you will forgive ham, clap their hands together, there's no more to be sad i'th' matter.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: I do, I do.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: I do not like this, peace boys, hear me one of you, everybody's part is come to an end but Ralph's, and he's left out.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Tis long of yourself sir, we have nothing to do with his part.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Raph come away, make on him as you have done of the rest, boys come.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Now good husband let him come out and die.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: He shall Nell, Raph come away quickly and die boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
'Twill be very unfit he should die sir, upon no occasion,
and in a comedy too.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Take you no care of that sir boy, is not his part at an end, think you, when he's dead? come away Raph.

div.stage: Enter Raph, with a forked arrow through his head.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: When I was mortal, this my costive corpse
Did lap up figs and raisins in the strand,
Where sitting I espied a lovely dame,
Whose master wrought with lingell and with all,
And under ground he vampied many a boot,
Straight did her love prick forth me, tender sprig
To follow feats of arms in warlike wise,
Through Waltham desert, where I did perform
Many achievements, and did lay on ground
Huge Barbaroso that insulting giant,
And all his captives soon set at liberty.
Then honour pricked me from my native soil,
Into Meldavia, where I gained the love
Of Pompiana his beloved daughter:
But yet proved constant to the black thumed maid
Susan, and scorned Pompiana's love:
Yet liberal I was and gave her pins,
And money for her father's officers.
I then returned home, and thrust myself
In action, and by all men chosen was
Lord of the may, where I did flourish it,
With scarves and rings, and posy in my hand,
After this action, I preferred was,
And chosen city captain at Mile-end,
With hat and feather and with leading staff,
And trained my men and brought them all off clear,
Save one man that bewrayed him with the noise.
But all these things I Raph did undertake,
Only for my beloved Susan's sake.
Then coming home, and sitting in my shop
With apron blew, death came unto my stall
To cheapen aquavitae, but ere I
Could take the bottle down, and fill a taste,
death caught a pound of pepper in his hand,
And sprinkled all my face and body o'er,
And in an instant vanished away.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: 'Tis a pretty fiction i'faith.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Then took I up my bow and shaft in hand,
And walked into Moorfields to cool myself,
But there grim cruel death met me again,
And shot this forked arrow through my head,
And now I faint, therefore be warned by me,
My fellows every one of forked heads.
Farewell all you good boys in merry London,
Ne'er shall we more upon Shrove-tuesday meet
And pluck down houses of iniquity.
My pain increaseth, I shall never more
Hold open, whilst another pumps both legs,
Nor daub a satin gown with rotten eggs:
Set up a stake, o never more I shall,
I die, fly, fly my soul to grocer's hall. o, o, o, etc.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Well said Raph, do your obeisance to the gentlemen and go your ways, well said Raph.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: methinks all we, thus kindly and unexpectedly reconciled should not depart without a song.

sp.speaker: Marchant
sp.p: A good motion.

sp.speaker: Old Mer.
sp.p: Strike up then.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Better music ne'er was known,
Than a choir of hearts in one.
Let each other that hath been,
Troubled with the gall or spleen:
Learn of us to keep his brow,
Smooth and plain as ours are now.
Sing though before the hour of dying
He shall rise and then be crying.
Hey ho, 'tis naught but mirth.
That keeps the body from the earth.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Come Nell, shall we go, the plays done.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay by my faith George, I have more manners than so, I'll speak to these gentlemen first: I thank you all gentlemen, for your patience and countenance to Raph, a poor fatherless child, and if I might see you at my house, it should go hard, but I would have a pottle of wine and a pipe of tobacco for you, for truly I hope you do like the youth, but I would be glad to know the truth: I refer it to your own discretions, whether you will applaud him or no, for I will wink, and whilst you shall do what you will, I thank you with all my heart, God give you good night; come George.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
